111.summary: Dyspnea is a common diagnostic challenge in the Emergency Department (ED). Delay in diagnosis will increase time to correct treatment and could impact outcome. Previous studies have shown excellent diagnostic performance of point of care ultrasound (POCUS) to detect and differentiate between several important diagnosis (e.g heart failure and pneumonia) in patients with dyspnea. However, in most studies POCUS is performed by physicians highly experienced in ultrasound and often studies have focused only on one or few diagnoses. The aim of this study is to compare the diagnostic accuracy of different diagnosis in dyspnoeic patients before and after a ED physician with limited training applies POCUS.
111.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Dyspnoea is a common symptom in the Emergency Department (ED). Despite the relatively high incidence of serious underlying conditions such as heart failure, pulmonary embolism and pneumonia, the diagnostic accuracy of these diagnoses might sometimes be low in the ED. Point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) might increase the diagnostic accuracy, but the findings of previous studies might be affected by selection bias. The aim of this study is to evaluate whether POCUS performed by a variety of emergency physicians improve diagnostic accuracy in patients with dyspnea.
Inclusion criteria: Adult patients presenting to the ED within the highest or second highest triage category with dyspnea or hypoxia will be eligible for the study.
Intervention: An emergency medicine specialist or resident will according to a structured protocol perform POCUS focusing on the heart, inferior vena cava and lungs. The foundings will be handed over to the initial physician with responsibility for diagnosing and the diagnosis will be dichotomised into being or not being the reason to present to the ED. The estimated likelihood of the diagnoses (heart failure, pulmonary embolism, pneumonia, COPD exacerbation, asthma exacerbation, bacterial pneumonia, viral pneumonia, pleural fluid and pericardial fluid) is documented before and after POCUS has been performed. Bloodsamples will be drawn after inclusion to assess biomarkers (N-terminal pro-B-type natriuretic peptide (pro-BNP), C-reactive protein (CRP) and white blood cell count). Chest imaging (X-ray or CT) will be performed at the ED physicians discretion according to routine diagnostic work-up.
Study type: Convenience sample prospective observational study.
Expected results: The investigators estimate that POCUS increases the diagnostic accuracy of underlying serious conditions in patients with dyspnoea. The investigators expect that the additional examination with POCUS will lead to a changed estimated likelihood of the six above mentioned diagnoses.
Ethics and dissemination: The study will be conducted in accordance with the Helsinki declaration and have ethical approval from the Regional Ethics Committee in Lund.
The results of the study should be published in peer reviewed scientific journals and submitted to a national or international conference. The findings should also be disseminated to clinicians in the ED and to other emergency physicians in Sweden and in other countries.

112.summary:
The goal of this prospective clinical trial is to improve patient compliance and performance of deep inspiration breath hold (DIBH) to further reduce the cardiac dose from left breast radiation, and to improve cooperation and patient satisfaction through an active and formal pre-treatment respiratory training program combined with relaxation training (R&R) in breast cancer patients undergoing adjuvant radiotherapy for left sided breast cancer.
The main questions the study aims to answer are:
Does the use of communication training and the use of relaxation techniques (R&R) reduce the Maximum dose to the heart (Dmax) and improve further heart dose parameters in deep inspiration during adjuvant radiotherapy for breast cancer?
Does R&R improve longitudinal anxiety and quality of life under patients undergoing DIBH adjuvant radiotherapy for left sided breast cancer?
Participants will be randomly assigned to either an experimental arm, which will receive the R&R, versus a standard arm that will not receive the R&R.
training program in the experimental arm includes breath hold training, music, and nature sounds that patients can listen to on an MP3 player
both groups complete standardized questionnaires about their well-being and satisfaction at prospective time points before, during the radiation treatment course, as well as at 6 weeks follow-up
Researchers will compare the R&R group (interventional arm) to current conventional DIBH instruction (standard group) to see if Dmax to the heart decreases and compliance and satisfaction under patients rises.
112.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Breast Cancer is a heterogeneously different disease in terms of pathophysiology, risk factors, clinical manifestations, disease progression and response to therapy, as well as prognosis and survival. While local management of breast cancer may provide adequate treatment in early stages, locally advanced breast cancers must be treated with surgery followed by combination chemotherapy and radiotherapy to improve long-term survival. In this setting radiation reduces the risk of local residual disease, recurrence, and distal metastases up to 10 years after radiation. Despite the benefits of radiotherapy there is little to no consideration of the effects on the patients' quality of life (QoL) while planning and delivering radiation therapy. Previous studies have shown that adjuvant therapies have a lasting and long-term impact on the quality of patients' lives, with more severe effects in patients undergoing chemotherapy and/or radiation. Radiation dose to the heart has been shown as a major contributor to cardiac complications in radiotherapy for left-sided breast cancer. Patients with left-sided breast cancer are therefore particularly at risk for radiation-induced coronary artery disease. Breast cancer patients who have undergone radiotherapy to left breast can experience reduced function of the heart muscle on the side of the breast receiving radiation, even many years after the treatment. The increased risk for cardiovascular disease is of particular concern for breast cancer survivors. Thus, the dose of radiation to organs outside the target, such as the heart, is important to consider in breast cancer therapy. Although recent advances in high precision radiation therapy have improved the targeting and consequently the reduction of dose to organs outside of the treatment target, the radiation dose to the heart continues to be a major concern. A number of strategies have been developed to keep the radiation dose to the heart as low as possible. Most recent developments involve respiratory techniques that enable radiation oncologists to position patients to maximize tumor target coverage and minimize cardiac exposure by utilizing the distance between the moving heart and the adjacent breast tissue during deep inspiratory breath holds. Patient cooperation to enable the radiation oncologist to achieve these goals is critical, but it is dependent on patients' respiratory skill and mental and psychological well-being. The investigator's preliminary results demonstrate that targeted DIBH training improves patients' cooperation and the ease of the DIBH procedure, reducing radiation dose to the heart. However, DIBH training regimens may not fully address patients' mental stress and anxiety that interfere with their ability to perform deep inspiration breath holds optimally. Preliminary data in diagnostic radiology procedures suggest that advanced communication and relaxation techniques, targeted to relieve anxiety and stress, improve patients' procedural performance and anxiety and comfort. The investigators propose to test this hypothesis by determining the impact of these training techniques in the context of radiation therapy for left-sided breast cancer on heart dose reduction. While radiation oncologists are aware of cardiac concerns, they lack tools to facilitate these psychological aspects of care in the context of radiation therapy. The investigators hypothesize that implementing both, DIBH Respiratory Training and advanced communication and Relaxation Training (R&R) will improve patients' DIBH performance skills and further reduce heart dose, while alleviating anxiety and stress and improving quality of life during and after radiation therapy. The results of this proposal will contribute to the development of novel patient-centered training and integrative health regimen to further improve the success of advanced technology-based cardiac dose reduction in breast cancer therapy, and improve cardiac health in breast cancer survivors.

The goal of this Single Arm Phase Ib clinical trial is to test standard of care chemotherapy and anti PD1 and IL1b to evaluate the safety and preliminary toxicity of this quadruplet regimen prior to resection in patients with pancreatic cancer. The main objectives it aims to answer are to:
Determine the recommended Phase II dose regimen of canakinumab and tislelizumab in combination with gemcitabine and nab-paclitaxel in patients with localized pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.
Estimate the proportion of patients who proceed to surgical resection.
Determine the safety and tolerability of canakimumab in combination with tislelizumab, nab-paclitaxel and gemcitabine

<|assistant|> Background (Rationale): Pancreatic cancer (PC) is the fourth leading cause of cancer-related death in the United States, with very low 5-year survival rates across all stages. Over 100,000 patients are diagnosed with PC in the U.S. With an estimated 45,750 PC death toll (male 22,400, female 23,350), the estimated pancreas cancer death is higher than the breast cancer and colon cancer combined, and the incidence is expected to grow in coming years due to an aging population, obesity rates and the high prevalence of heavy smoking. Unfortunately, the current treatment options for patients with resectable PC do not produce durable disease control once a tumor has recurred. While chemotherapy helps reduce the chance of disease recurrence and improves survival, this effect is typically short lived. The interleukin-1 beta (IL-1 beta) pathway, an inflammatory pathway, plays an important role in tumorigenesis, cancer progression, angiogenesis and metastasis. Activation of this pathway is associated with aggressive, metastatic and treatment-resistant cancer. Inhibitors of the components of the pathway can prevent migration, invasion and the proliferation of cancer cells in several preclinical cancer models. Canakinumab (ACZ885), a monoclonal antibody that neutralizes IL-1beta, and tislelizumab (BGB-A1217), an immuno-oncology therapy that can enhance a patient's own anti-cancer immune responses and enable the patient's T-cells to target cancer cells, offer new therapeutic approaches for PC. The combination of nab-paclitaxel, gemcitabine and a IL1beta-targeting antibody in a neoadjuvant setting has the potential to improve outcomes for patients with newly diagnosed resectable PC. The goal of this study is to determine the safety and effectiveness of a combination of tislelizumab, canakinumab, Gemcitabine and nab-paclitaxel in patients with newly diagnosed resectable pancreatic cancer. Official Title: A Phase IB Study to Determine the Safety and Tolerability of Canakinumab and Tislelizumab in Combination With Nab-Paclitaxel and Gemcitabine in the Neo-adjuvant Treatment of Patients With Pancreatic Cancer Conditions: Pancreatic Cancer Intervention / Treatment: 1. Drug: Canakinumab - Canakinumab is a monoclonal antibody that neutralizes IL-1beta. Canakinumab will be administered at a dose of 250 mg via subcutaneous injection on day 1 of every 28-day cycle. 2. Drug: Tislelizumab - Tislelizumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the co-inhibitory immune checkpoint receptor PD-1 expressed on T-cells, enabling T-cells to better target cancer cells. Tislelizumab will be administered at a dose of 300 mg via intravenous infusion. 3. Drug: Nab-Paclitaxel - Nab-Paclitaxel will be administered intravenously at a concentration of 125 mg/m2 on day 1 of every 28-day cycle. 4. Drug: Gemcitabine - Gemcitabine will be administered intravenously at a dose of 1000 mg/m2 on day 1, 8 and 15 of every 28-day cycle. 114.summary: Black and Latino youth are more likely to experience an unmet mental health or psychosocial need than do their white counterparts. Schools and primary care clinics are ideal hubs to provide mental health, healthcare, social services, and prevention to students and families who otherwise face barriers to care. Using Participatory Design and Community Partnered Participatory Research (CPPR) for app development, mobile technology is designed to optimize access to wellness resources. The proposed intervention is a model of care using technology and navigators for connecting youth ages 13-22 to mental health care and supports. The app is co-created with the community and supported by culturally responsive individuals called family and youth navigators, in schools and primary care clinics. Outcomes are measured using the cascade of care model.

The objective of this research is to design and test a step wedged implementation of a digital supported intervention using family and youth peer navigators. The study aims to improve access to mental health navigation, resources, and a wellness app, which can improve outcomes for children (ages 12-22) with mental health needs. The study is taking place in Los Angeles, specifically in 10 schools selected for their racial and ethnic diversity, and in 10 primary care clinics in Riverside County, where 20% of families have no health insurance and 62% are at or below poverty levels. The study will utilize a Participatory Design process to co-design a digital tool and peer navigation strategies. Once designed, all schools and clinics will enter a care as usual period for 1-3 years and then cross over to receive the app and peer navigation. 115.summary: Cesarean section is the most prevalent operation among women globally, 10-15% (1, 2). Recent research has shown Egypt to be the third-largest country globally, with an estimated 52% cesarean sections (3). However, the cesarean section has many serious complications, including the primary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) (4). During labor, the average blood loss is about 300 to 400 ml. Bleeding postpartum is known as losing over five hundred milliliter of blood following a vaginal birth and losing over one thousand milliliter after the cesarean section (5). The prime cause of maternal death rate is postpartum bleeding, predominately in poor countries, and the estimated mortality number due to postpartum bleeding is one hundred thousand per year (6). Therefore, it is essential to reduce bleeding during and after CS to diminish maternal mortality and morbidity (7). The most successful technique for decreasing PPH is the active third stage labor management, requiring prophylactic uterotonic drugs like oxytocin, ergometrine malate, prostaglandins (E1, E2, and F2α), and combinations of them, or hemostatic agent as tranexamic acid (Kapron) and Etamsylate (Dicynon) (8, 9).
115.model_output:
<|assistant|>
The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of tranexamic acid and oxytocin injection on reducing risk of postpartum hemorrhage after cesarean delivery. Fifty primigravida women at term pregnancy, undergoing elective cesarean delivery, will be included in this clinical study at admission to the labor ward. The study is divided into 2 equal groups assigned randomly. In TXA group (n=25): 1 g from tranexamic acid (kapron®, Amoun, Egypt) shall also be watered down in 10 cc of Saline, and 5 cc shall be injected in each uterine corn before the placenta is separated. To the oxytocin group (n = 25): 5 I.U of oxytocin (syntocinone 5 I.U/1ML NONARTIS-EGYPT) shall be watered down in 10 cc of saline, and 5 cc shall be injected into each uterine corn before the placental separation. The estimated blood loss, and the need of extra uterotonic drugs are measured.

116.summary:
The ReceptIVFity acts as a timing-tool for prediction of optimal pregnancy chances and provides insight into the patient's current (two months after sampling) success rate of an IVF/IVF-ICSI treatment. Benefits of physician decision treatment in case of an unfavorable vaginal profile and a low chance of achieving a pregnancy include reducing unnecessary morbidity and treatment cycles, stress and disappointment, while increasing efficacy of the treatment and lowering the costs needed to achieve a pregnancy.
The goal of this prospective, clinical non-invasive randomized controlled study, with an additional observational study arm (for women of non-European origin) in naïve IVF or IVF/ICSI patients is to evaluate the efficiency of Shared Decision Making compared to Physician Decision in terms of
the success probability of an IVF cycle,
the proportion of women with a successful pregnancy
the number of unsuccessful IVF cycles.
Randomization component Women of European origin will be randomized 1:1 to either the shared decision group or the physician decision group. All women of European origin may undergo one to three cycles of IVF/IVF-ICSI reimbursed by the health insurance. The follow-up ends after the outcome of the last of these cycles has been determined. The desired outcome of the IVF or IVF/ICSI treatment is a successful pregnancy, i.e., a pregnancy with a heart-beat at 12 weeks of gestation.
Observational component Women of non-European origin are invited to take part in an observational component of this study. Without further evaluation of the results of their vaginal microbiome, they will continue with the IVF/IVF-ICSI cycle. Women eligible for participation are naïve patients and the follow-up ends after the outcome of the first IVF/IVF-ICSI cycle has been determined.

118.summary: Acute myocardial infarction (AMI) remains the leading cause of death worldwide. In this scenario, early coronary reperfusion is the main therapeutic strategy as it substantially reduces mortality. Paradoxically, however, reperfusion triggers additional tissue damage that accounts for about 50% of the infarcted heart mass, i.e., ischemia and reperfusion injury (IRL). In this context, sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) is a sphingolipid synthesized by sphingosine kinases (Sphk), carried in plasma bound to high-density lipoprotein (HDL) and released after cellular damage such as LIR. Particularly, in animal models of AMI, therapies targeting downstream S1P receptor signaling triggered by HDL/S1P are able to promote endothelial barrier functions and attenuate secondary damage to LIR. Thus, the molecular control of sphingosine kinase 1 (Sphk1) transcription during LIR in vivo or during hypoxia/reoxygenation (H/R) in vitro may represent an important mechanism for maintaining endothelial homeostasis since it promotes the generation of S1P and this may promote subsequent HDL enrichment. Thus, the role of pioglitazone hydrochloride 45mg/day for five days in volunteers undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting (BVR) will be investigated in order to verify the vascular expression of SPhk1, transcriptome and vascular proteome remodeling, as well as S1P content in HDL.

<|assistant|>
The main objective of this study is to evaluate the role of pioglitazone in vascular Sphk1 expression and of the proteome and transcriptome remodeling mediated by S1P in coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) in individuals with diabetes mellitus and with a history of heart disease for the last five years. Research hypothesis: Pioglitazone can induce vascular transcriptional and proteome remodeling through S1P action; the action of S1P can be monitored by increased expression of S phk1 and increased S1P content in isolated HDL. It is expected that pioglitazone increase 10-fold Sphk1 expression and S1P content in isolated HDL. Pioglitazone 45 mg/day for five days after hospital stay, will be administered to the randomized patients from the cardiac surgery outpatient clinic.

119.summary: This single-dose, randomized, open label, five-treatment, five-period, five-sequence crossover study was performed to assess pharmacodynamics (PD) and pharmacokinetics (PK) of three new developed coated Glucose beads formulations (containing glucose (8 g) and caffeine), one coated Glucose beads formulation (containing glucose (8 g)) and one uncoated Glucose beads formulation (containing Glucose (8 g) and caffeine) after single-dose administration (fasting conditions) in 20 obese healthy subjects. After an overnight fasting of at least 10 hours the subjects were administered either glucose (8 g) or glucose (8 g) and caffeine starting at 8:00 (time 0; administration time was staggered beginning at 8:00 for the first group of subjects) in sitting position. At least 3 days wash-out period was kept between each treatment periods.

120.summary:
Introduction: Panoramic radiography quality can be impaired by some errors such as positioning errors. Palatoglossal air space shadow error is one of the most common positioning errors and it's due to the tongue not sticking to the roof of the palate. Techniques used to deal with this error might help prevent unnecessary radiation to patients and save them time and money. The study aimed to investigate to investigate the effects of using celluloid matrix and edible tapes (fruit leather and chewing gum) on reducing the palatoglossal air space shadow error in panoramic imaging Methods: In our study, 270 patients referred to the Department of Radiology were randomised into three groups: a control group, a celluloid matrix group, and an edible tapes group. Before panoramic imaging, all patients were instructed to adhere their tongues to the roof of their mouths, with the distinction that for the celluloid matrix and edible tapes groups, patients were asked to place celluloid tapes, fruit leathers, or chewing gums on their tongues before doing so. The routine imaging process was then performed, and the results were compared across groups to evaluate the incidence of palatoglossal air space shadow error.

121.summary:
Type of this study: Prospective randomized controlled study. Purpose: The aim of this study is to compare the acute effect of pain level, lower extremity functionality level and plantar fascia flexibility in patients with plantar fasciitis receiving Exportacorporeal Shock Therapy (ESWT).
To compare the acute effect of pain level, lower extremity functionality level and plantar fascia flexibility in patients with plantar fasciitis who received KT application in addition to ESWT treatment.
To compare the acute effect of pain level, lower extremity functionality level and plantar fascia flexibility in patients with plantar fasciitis receiving placebo application.
90 volunteers will be included in the study as ESWT (n=30), placebo ESWT (n=30), ESWT and KT (n=30) application groups. How effective is ESWT, ESWT and Kinesiotape versus placebo ESWT acutely in the treatment of plantar fasciitis?
121.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Plantar fasciitis is a common disease in athletes and the sedentary population, accompanied by pain and limitation of foot function. Hot-cold tampon application, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, heel cushion, night splint, plantar fascia and Achilles stretching exercise, kinesio taping (CT), ultrasound, and extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT) are the methods used in the treatment of plantar fasciitis. The aim of this study is to compare the acute effect on pain level, lower extremity functionality and plantar fascia flexibility in patients with plantar fasciitis receiving ESWT, patients with plantar fasciitis receiving KinesioTape in addition to ESWT, and patients with plantar fasciitis receiving placebo ESWT. Age (years), height (cm) and body weight (kg) measured with an adult scale with a mechanical height measure, gender, occupation, affected side and dominant side of patients diagnosed with plantar fasciitis will be recorded. Patients will be divided into three groups: ESWT (Group 1), ESWT and Kinesiotape (Group 2), and Placebo/Sham (Group 3) application groups. ESWT (BTL-6000SWT, UK); A single session will be applied at 10 Hz frequency, 2.5 Barr energy and 2000 shocks/session. For KT application, a tape consisting of 96% cotton, 4% lycra, water-resistant, porous and adhesive, 5 cm wide and 0.5 mm thick will be used. Taping will be done after the ESWT session and the tape will be asked to remain for a week. After the first examination of the physical therapy and rehabilitation specialist physician in the placebo/Sham group, the patient will be listened to the sound of the device through the audio device and ESWT application will be applied without the device working. For clinical follow-up of the patients, visual pain scale (VAS) score, lower extremity functional scale score will be used before and one week after treatment, and plantar fascia flexibility will be evaluated.

122.summary: The development of adult intimate relationships and the transition into couplehood are part of most people's life cycles, but these transitions become very challenging for individuals diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in as much as social interactions, emotional communication, and reciprocity, which are essential for interpersonal relationships, are made more difficult due to the condition itself. In the Adult ASD Clinic of National Taiwan University Hospital, we observe that the wives of the ASD husband suffer from long-term frustration, loneliness and helplessness, and are frequently experience anxiety and depression, that in turns changes the family's function and impacts on children's mental health. To date, there are limited intervention models focusing on couple therapy for ASD adults (or neurodiverse couple). Given the strong needs of clinical service, this study aims to identify the common problems of the ASD couples and develop a program to improve their partner relationships.
122.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Adults with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) often experience a decrease in quality of life and an increase of social and daily living difficulties. ASD couples are reported to have greater conflicts and lower levels of communication and companionship. Studies have suggested that couple interventions, especially group therapy, are useful to help ASD couples to improve empathy, relationship satisfaction, communication, and daily living skills. The aim of the present study is to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of the couple intervention program for the adults with ASD.
Inclusion Criteria: 
Inclusion Criteria: 
one person of each couple has either Autism Spectrum Disorder diagnosis or the autism spectrum quotient scoring above or equal to 26 ability to communicate in Chinese Wechsler Intelligence scoring above 70 Exclusion Criteria: 
Psychiatric disorder (i.e. schizophrenia, substance abuse) inability to communication (i.e. visual or auditory impairment)

The main measures include the Autism Spectrum Quotient, Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule (ADOS), Empathy Quotient, Quality of socialization questionnaire (QSQ), Social Responsiveness Scale (SRS), and YoungMania Rating Scale (YMRS). The measures will be repeated at 6 months follow-up.
Study Plan (within 6 months): 
Study Plan (within 6 months) 
Participants will receive the 1 hour session/week, 1 hour of homework/week for 10 weeks.
Participants will be informed the study objectives and procedures. Participants are allowed to drop out at any time if they cannot complete the program.
All participants will attend 10 1-hour sessions per fortnight. Therapist will conduct couple group therapy based on cognitive behavioral methods and focus on the following:
1. Introduction of I statements.
2. Focus of each conversation (e.g., emotion acknowledgement, self-assurance and positive feedback, teamwork and cooperation, reflection).
Couples will be asked to communicate with each other in Chinese. Homework will be instructed to reinforce the learned skills.

123.summary:
Covid-19 has the potential to affect physical, cognitive and psychological functions in multiple ways. It has been clear that a significant proportion of patients with Covid-19 develop long-term symptoms. The term post COVID-19 condition (defined by WHO) is used to describe the wide range of prolonged symptoms following the infection. Patients may need specialized rehabilitation to be able to meet the complex symptoms and problems that may arise. A more specific syndrome that seems to occur more frequently than expected in the group of non-hospitalized patients with post COVID-19 condition is the postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS).
A randomized controlled design will be used to evaluate the effects of individual tailored physical exercise in patients with POTS after Covid-19.
Participants: Adults (>18 years) with post COVID-19 condition and diagnosed with POTS (n=60) will be included. Exclusion criteria: known pregnancy, cancer, already ongoing individual physical exercise (specific for POTS), or not able to perform measurements and/or intervention.
Procedure and outcomes: The primary outcomes are objectively measured time in upright position and health-related quality of life. Secondary outcomes are: physical activity, physical capacity, work ability and disease specific symptoms measured with tests and questionnaires.
Prior to randomization baseline measurements will be performed, aswell as after 16 weeks, 6 months and 12 months.
Intervention: Participants randomized to intervention will receive standard care and undergo a individually designed physical exercise program during 16 weeks, supervised and guided by a physiotherapist. The intervention will consist of different exercises to enhance muscle strength and endurance. Progression will be according to a program (based on previous feasibility studie) but should be halted if post exertional malaise (PEM) or other problems occur.
Controls: Participants randomized to control will receive standard care during 16 weeks.
Measurements of both groups (control and intervention) will be repeated after completion of a period of 16 weeks.

124.summary: Branch atheromatous disease (BAD)-related stroke, characterized by subcortical single infarcts without severe stenosis of the large artery, but with a clear atherosclerotic mechanism, is now regarded as a separate stroke type. 126.summary: Epidemiological studies have shown that OSA is closely related to the occurrence and development of cardiovascular diseases, especially hypertension. At present, there are 66 million patients with moderate to severe OSA in China, and the current diagnosis and treatment of OSA is mainly completed in the sleep center of the hospital, which is time-consuming and laborious, resulting in the delayed diagnosis and treatment of a large number of patients, making about 80% of potential OSA patients have not been diagnosed and treated in time. With the development of the Internet technologies, telemedicine has been increasingly applied to the diagnosis, treatment and management of chronic diseases with its advantages of convenience, interactivity, efficiency, sharing, coherence and breaking through the limitations of time and space. Our center has initially built a remote diagnosis and treatment management model for OSA. Compared with the traditional medical model, the medical and health economic analysis shows that the OSA diagnosis and treatment model based on telemedicine is more cost-effective, but its clinical efficacy needs to be further verified. Hypertension is a common complication in OSA patients, and continuous positive airway pressure (PAP) has a significant hypertensive effect in the treatment of OSA. However, whether clinical management based on remote diagnosis and treatment mode can achieve the same therapeutic effect as traditional face-to-face diagnosis and treatment mode in improving ambulate blood pressure in OSA patients needs to be further clarified. This study will compare the improvement of ambulatory blood pressure management in patients with hypertension under the new telemedicine mode and the traditional medical mode through a single-center randomized controlled trial, so as to optimize the diagnosis and treatment process of OSA patients with hypertension, establish a more convenient and efficient remote diagnosis and treatment mode with reliable clinical outcome, and provide a theoretical basis for subsequent multi-center research and promotion
126.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Patients with OSA often suffer from hypertension. A large-scale retrospective observational study found that the prevalence of OSA in hypertension patients with daytime sleepiness or sleep disturbances was more than 80 percent. There is a close relationship between 24-hour ambulatory systolic blood pressure in OSA patients, 24-hour systolic blood pressure increased by 5.2 mmHg and 6.5 mmHg in uncomplicated OSA patients and OSA patients with hypertension. The blood pressure in daytime sleepiness and sleep disturbances are the most serious, but the rhythm pattern of 24-hour blood pressure is often irregular, and there is no large scale prospective study on this. The blood pressure improvement of OSA patients during the treatment of OSA may be mainly the normalization of blood pressure rhythm. The purpose of our study is to observe changes in blood pressure rhythm of OSA patients after 3 months of treatment with CPAP device. We want to compare the blood pressure after 3 months of treatment between the inpatient care and telemedicine, and then to determine whether CPAP device treatment can effectively improve the out-of-time blood pressure rhythm of OSA patients after 3 months treatment, and to explore the effective intervention mode, so as to improve the clinical prognosis of OSA patients, promote the use of telemedicine, and reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease. Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is defined as an apnea-hypopnea index (AHI), consisting of at least one apnea (cessation of respiration for at least 10 seconds) or at least 5 hypopneas (at least 50% decrease in airflow and arousal), ≥5 but <15/h, and/or a 4% decrease in oxygen saturation. The 3-month follow-up will be done at the sleep center, and the blood pressure rhythm will be measured and questionnaires will be completed. If the blood pressure after treatment improves significantly (decreased ≥15 mmHg), patients will undergo a follow-up for a further 6 months by telephone to monitor the recurrence of hypertension and the changes in blood pressure rhythm. A total of 55 OSA patients in each arm will be required to recruit, so 110 patients (55 in each arm) will be recruited in our study.

127.summary:
Effective management of postoperative pain is a priority for women undergoing cesarean delivery. Despite availability of modern analgesics, postoperative pain management remains a challenge.
One opportunity to enhance the analgesic effect of the pharmacological treatments given to people suffering from pain (and not just pain) is through increasing the expectations for pain relief following treatment. Although much knowledge has been accumulated about the significant effect of expectations on pain, virtually all evidence are based on experimental studies carried out in laboratory settings, and there is a need to investigate how this knowledge could translated into improved clinical care.
The aim of the current study is to examine whether the communication style between the nursing staff and the patient during analgesic administration will affect the results of pain relief treatment in the mother-newborn ward after cesarean section. As another goal, the study will examine whether relevant patient's characteristics will predict the effectiveness of the treatment.

<|assistant|>
Background: The use of analgesics for pain management after the operative delivery of a baby by cesarean section is widespread. However, the success of the analgesic is partly dependent on the manner in which medications are administered, including how the delivery of the medication is communicated to the patient. However, even when administering an effective analgesic, patients may continue experiencing significant pain. One potential explanation for this phenomenon is that verbal communication plays an important role in how the patient will perceive the analgesic efficacy. The current study aims to investigate whether enhanced verbal communication about the administration of medication can modify pain perception following cesarean section, and whether the efficacy of analgesic medication varies with an enhanced pain management training. Methods: The study will be carried out in the maternity ward at Carmel Hospital. The study population will include patients who are about to undergo an elective cesarean section under spinal anesthesia. The recruitment will be done pre-surgery. Following consent, participants will receive an explanation about how to assess pain and will fill out the research questionnaires. Communication is the independent variable in this study, which has 2 levels - the increased communication arm (intervention) and the normal communication arm (standard of care). Each arm will include 40 patients who will be randomly divided between the arms. The dependent variable is the treatment efficacy, based on the changes in the intensity of the patient's pain one hour after the administration of analgesic. Assessments will be performed one and two hours following spinal anesthesia and 12 hours following cesarean section.

128.summary:
Low-dose CT (LDCT) screening for lung cancer (LCS) has been shown to reduce lung cancer specific mortality in multiple randomised controlled trials. However, although LDCT screening has been demonstrated to reduce cancer- specific mortality, there remain outstanding questions regarding how screening can be implemented. In particular, indeterminate nodules are common, and can be challenging to distinguish from benign nodules on CT appearances alone. Furthermore, distinguishing cancers which are likely to become clinically significant from those that will remain indolent is challenging, but essential to prevent over-treatment and overdiagnosis. There is significant interest in using a multi-modal approach to LCS, incorporating biomarkers obtained from minimally-invasive samples alongside LDCT to improve ability to recognise clinically-significant lung cancers at an early stage.
The Targeted Lung Health Check (TLHC) programme is an NHS programme with the aim of using LDCT screening in appropriately high-risk individuals to improve early diagnosis and survival in lung cancer. The North Central London TLHC programme started in December 2022.
The purpose of the ALPINE study is to develop a platform to allow collection of minimally-invasive samples from participants undergoing screening within the North Central London TLHC programme. The use of such biomarkers in the diagnosis of lung cancer is a rapidly developing field and novel techniques and technologies are continuously under development. The ALPINE study will generate a cohort with matched biosamples, CT scans and clinical data which will be uniquely well placed to serve to develop or validate biomarkers in lung cancer screening and risk prediction.

In this observational study, we will recruit 2000 participants (n=2000) to establish a molecular characterization of their peripheral blood samples for identification of molecular-based biomarker signature associated with lung cancer risk.
In addition, 500 individuals may be approached for an optional biopsy using bronchoscopy in order for the researchers to also study the DNA and RNA from the lung tissue, and the DNA and RNA expressed by the immune cells found in the lung tissue.

129.summary:
The goal of this clinical trial is to compare the effectiveness of a pharmaceutical care protocol via teleconsultation in the management of uncontrolled hypertension with pharmaceutical care carried out in elderly patients assisted in primary health care. The main questions it aims to answer are:
How effective is a pharmaceutical care protocol via teleconsultation on the clinical outcomes of elderly people with uncontrolled hypertension, when compared to in-person pharmaceutical care?
How effective is a pharmaceutical care protocol via teleconsultation in adherence to the treatment of elderly people with hypertension, when compared to in-person pharmaceutical care?
Participants will undergo four visits. Two visits will be for the application of instruments and measurement of clinical parameters to be carried out at the beginning and end of follow-up (visits 1 and 4). These will be carried out in a pharmacist's office at the pharmacy by previously trained pharmacists and pharmacy students. Visits 2 and 3 will be pharmaceutical consultations to be carried out in person and/or via telepharmacy.
Researchers will compare pharmaceutical care via telepharmacy with in-person pharmaceutical care to see how effective these services are in controlling blood pressure in elderly patients with uncontrolled blood pressure.
129.model_output:
<|assistant|>
The objective is to evaluate the impact of pharmaceutical care via telephone through the Celeste randomized clinical trial, with 200 elderly patients with controlled blood pressure, allocated to in-person or telepharmacy groups. The data will be collected at baseline and during the follow-up of the 3 months of the study. The intervention strategy consists of the standardization and documentation of pharmaceutical care in the experimental group, carried out by a trained pharmacist through telephone contact with the patients. An educational intervention is applied, with counseling, therapeutic reconciliation, clinical monitoring and resolution of medication-related problems. The data collection tools have pre-defined criteria for inclusion of patients in the project. It is proposed to create a database for collection, management and control of information, providing tools for analysis of socio-demographic, clinical and epidemiological characteristics. The statistical analysis will be done separately for each group, using the SPSS 20 statistical software. A 95% confidence level (α = 0.05) will be used for data analysis, with non-parametric tests for numerical variables and chi-square tests for categorical variables. There will be a descriptive characterization of the sample in the experimental and control groups, and their clinical characteristics on admission. The following comparisons will be made: clinical importance of the prescription, controlled blood pressure, adherence to the treatment and clinical relevance of the interventions, as well as patient satisfaction. The hypothesis is that there will be a positive effect on the variables of the study, such as controlled blood pressure, treatment adherence and clinical relevance of the interventions between the two groups. This project aims to generate knowledge in pharmaceutical care, highlighting and improving current care services for the elderly. Additionally, it will add to the growing evidence regarding the effectiveness of telepharmacy in public health primary care.

130.summary:
Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a condition associated with hypoxemia due to noncardiogenic causes and results in high mortality. However, the epidemiology and treatment strategy for ARDS may have changed significantly due to the accumulation of a large body of knowledge, following the two-year pandemic of the novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) of which the primary manifestation is ARDS. To improve the quality of ICU care that patients receive after admission to the ICU, a variety of academic societies, including the Japanese Society of Intensive Care Medicine and the Society of Critical Care Medicine, are currently developing evidence-based guidelines and consensus guidelines and statements regarding ABCDEF bundles, nutritional therapy, ICU diary. The ABCDEF bundle, nutritional therapy, and ICU diary have been developed and are being promoted for implementation in hospitals around the world. The implementation of evidence-based ICU care is strongly recommended, especially for patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome who frequently require ventilators to maintain their lives, because their patient outcomes are worse than those who were admitted to ICU with other causes.
However, there is still little evidence on how the quality of ICU care (compliance rate) correlates with patient prognosis and outcomes, and there are currently no clear goals or indicators for the ICU care we should develop.
This study aims to investigate the epidemiology and treatments given to the patients and evaluate the implementation of evidence-based ICU care and its association with the outcomes of patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome admitted to the ICU. The contents of mechanical ventilation settings, respiratory conditions, and the evidence-based ICU care, such as analgesia, sedation, rehabilitation, and nutrition, given to the patients will be collected in a daily basis.
Aim 1: Epidemiology Aim 2: Treatments Aim 3: Evidence-based ICU care Aim 4: ARDS related Post Intensive Care Syndrome

131.summary:
The state of skin health impacts not only on the general health of individuals, but also on mental health. Ultraviolet radiation (UV) is one of the main external factors that causes skin ageing, producing photo-aging, characterized by multiple alterations in the skin such as the appearance of wrinkles, dryness, erythema, alterations in the pigmentation, inflammation and increased fragility.
Several studies show that polyphenols extracts, including pomegranate extracts, have beneficial effects on various skin characteristics induced by photoaging by modulating internal factors that lead to changes associated with photoaging. Among these internal factors are oxidative stress, glycation stress caused by an accumulation of advances glycation end-products (AGEs), inflammation, and the composition of the intestinal and skin microbiota.
Pomanox® is a polyphenolic extract derived from pomegranate for which antioxidant activity and positive effects on the metabolism of collagen and hyaluronic acid have been shown in previous in vitro studies.

The hypothesis of the study is that the consumption of Pomanaox®P30 will have beneficial effects on skin ageing in humans through the modulation of the metabolism of collagen, hyaluronic acid and the inflammatory system, the inhibition of the production of reactive oxygen species and AGEs, and/or changes in the intestinal and skin microbiota composition. The main objective of the study is to evaluate the effect of consuming two doses of Pomanaox®P30, 367 mg/die (Group 1) and 700 mg/die (Group 2), compared to a control group (maltodextrin with the same appearance and taste) for 3 consecutive months on hyperpigmented skin spots in 66 humans aged 30-65 years with Fitzpatrick skin phototype II-IV. Additionally, the effect of the two treatments will be evaluated in different parameters related to the appearance and health of the skin, as well as the levels of blood and urine biomarkers.

132.summary: PROMED is a prospective, single center translational multiple cohort study to investigate the association of prostate medication and gut microbiota. The main aim is to investigate how prostate hormonal therapy (5-ARI, ADT) affects gut microbiota composition. Aalso study metabolic characteristics in the gut and systemic circulation in men with different medications will be studied. In addition, the effect of gut microbiota on patient's response to medications will be investigated. The medicines used in the study to treat benign prostate hyperplasia are dutasteride and finasteride and a combination of dutasteride and tamsulosin. LHRH antagonist degarelix is used as a medication to treat patients with cancer. The dosages of 5-ARI medication: dutasteride 0,5mg x1 or finasteride 5mg x1 or combination of dutasteride and tamsulosin 0,5/0,4mg x1. The starting dose of LHRH antagonist degarelix is 120mgx2 and the maintenance dose is 80mgx1. The medication for PCa is planned according to the protocol but so that each subject receives degarelix at the beginning of treatment and one month after initiation. Thereafter, the medication is continued according to the clinician's assessment. The study is carried out in Turku University Hospital and University of Turku.

Prostate cancer (PCa) is the most common male cancer in Finland and most western countries. PCa is known to affect the quality of life as well as life span of the men diagnosed with it. Although a lot of effort has been put into the prevention and treatment of this type cancer, there are still significant knowledge gaps concerning the underlying pathophysiological mechanisms. Epidemiological data suggest that there is a 40-fold variation in the incidence of PCa between different populations. In this context, epidemiology provides evidence that lifestyle, including smoking habits, nutrition and physical activity, influence PCa risk. The microbial colonization, i.e. gut microbiota, present in the intestine is known to affect many metabolic processes and diseases in the human body. Interestingly, emerging evidence suggest that gut microbiota composition might also affect PCa risk.

The purpose of our study is to better understand the role of gut microbiota composition in benign prostate hyperplasia (SHPB) and PCa. For the clinical part of the study, a cohort of men with benign prostate hyperplasia (BPH) receiving androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) for prostate cancer will be recruited. The samples will be collected before and after medication that affects the levels of androgen hormone (ADT) or 5-α reductase inhibitors, respectively. 

In addition, the following metabolic factors will be assessed:
- Prostate-specific antigen (PSA)
- Steroid hormones: testosterone, DHT, estradiol to testosterone ratio, sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG)
- PTH (parathyroid hormone)
- FGF23 (Fibroblast growth factor 23)
- Microbiota composition in the gut and feces
- Fecal and serum steroid metabolites that can be determined using liquid chromatography and mass spectrometry

The microbiota composition will be assessed using 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing. 

The outcomes of the study should provide a better understanding of the potential role of gut microbiota in PCa and benign prostate hyperplasia, and may lead to the creation of novel non-invasive diagnostic and prognostic methods for these diseases. Additionally, insight gained from this project might pave the way for novel lifestyle-based interventions aimed at lowering the risk of PCa.

133.summary:
In France, about 5000 new people with a primary malignant brain tumor are diagnosed each year. The most common primary tumors are gliomas, originating from glial cells (astrocytomas and oligodendrogliomas). Low-grade gliomas are mildly aggressive, but they often evolve into a more malignant form.
Mutations in the genes encoding isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) are found in about 80% of low-grade gliomas and are associated with a favorable prognosis. Remarkably, IDH-mutated gliomas are characterized by a specific cellular metabolism causing the accumulation of D-2-hydroxyglutarate (2HG) in tumor cells. 2HG can be detected in vivo using 1H magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) and is recognized as a unique, noninvasive biomarker of IDH-mutated gliomas. Noninvasive detection of IDH mutations via 2HG MRS represents a crucial step for decision-making and patient care.
A subset of IDH-mutated tumors also presents a complete deletion of 1p and 19q chromosome arms (1p/19q codeletion). The 1p/19q codeletion is specifically linked to the oligodendroglial histologic subtype and it has been associated with a better patient outcome. However, the biological effects of this genetic alteration are still unclear and in vivo markers are lacking. Recently, we reported the first in vivo detection of the cystathionine molecule in human brain gliomas using MRS and explored the association between cystathionine accumulation and 1p/19q codeletion in gliomas.
In this project, the investigation team will combine cutting edge MRI and MRS techniques for metabolic and microstructural characterization of brain tumors with the aim of providing novel reliable noninvasive biomarkers of tumor genetic subtypes. These methods will enable noninvasive identification of IDH-mutated gliomas and, potentially, 1p/19q codeleted gliomas. In addition, the researchers will investigate the utility of 2HG, cystathionine and MRI microstructural markers to monitor tumor response to anti-cancer treatments and tumor progression.
The outputs of this project, altogether, may open new avenues to a better understanding of the pathophysiological mechanisms of oncogenesis and the design of new treatments for gliomas.
133.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Gliomas are the most frequent malignant brain tumors in adults. The grade of malignancy is assessed according to the IDH mutational status and the 1p19q codeletion status, established on an ex vivo tumor specimen.
In the case of glioblastoma and metastatic glioma, the survival prognosis is poor. For other grades, patients have a good prognosis when these tumors are fully removed. Tumor recurrences are frequent and associated with the development of resistance mechanisms.
The diffusion MRI technique and metabolic spectroscopy are imaging modalities that could be used to distinguish recurrences from regrowths and to better target the biological status of the tumor.
In gliomas, the concentration of 2-Hydroxyglutarate (2HG) is measured by MRS at the time of surgery and 6 months after the beginning of treatment (chemoradiotherapy or targeted treatment). The concentration of 2HG is correlated with the histologic status and 1p19q codeletion status. The goal is to assess the evolution of 2HG concentrations in various recurrences situations: no treatment, adjuvant chemotherapies or adjuvant targeted treatment (L1 inhibitor).
This study is performed on 30 patients operated for a glioma. A MRS examination is performed before and after tumor removal to quantify metabolites, particularly 2HG. This examination is also performed 6 months and 1 year after the start of treatment on the patients according to the evolution of tumor and/or to the appearance of new symptoms.
Patients with a glioma in the second grade, who benefit from a surgical resection, are included in a sub-study (study2).
Patients with a glioma in the third grade without surgical resection are included in a sub-study (study3). 
This study is not considered a clinical trial because it is a sub-study of a diagnostic test.
The results of this study will help to optimize treatment strategies, by selecting patients responding to a certain treatment and identifying those with refractory tumors. 
MRI will not be the only selection criteria of the study but this exam will provide additional information to optimize the therapeutic strategy of patients.

134.summary:
Objectives
Primary objective:
• To determine the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of Hydroxyurea and thalidomide in beta-thalassemia patients.
Secondary objective:
• To determine the change in liver and spleen size of beta-thalassemia patients on the combination therapy.
A single-arm non-randomized trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of combination therapy of hydroxyurea and thalidomide in beta-thalassemia patients. Participants were monitored for six months on Hydroxyurea alone and then the combination therapy of hydroxyurea and thalidomide was started. Findings of physical examination, vital signs, laboratory, and ultrasound findings were recorded at baseline, during, and end of the study.
The assessment of treatment outcomes was conducted at the 1-year, 2-year, and 3-year follow-up points during the combination therapy period, categorizing patients as either good responders, responders, or non-responders.

The efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of hydroxyurea (HU) and thalidomide were evaluated in beta-thalassemia major and intermedia patients. Patients who did not show a significant response to hydroxyurea were included in the study. Their treatment response was evaluated during the HU monotherapy period. For the combination therapy period, HU with thalidomide was orally administered, with an initial dosage of 2-5 mg/kg/day after hydroxyurea at a daily dosage of 10-20 mg/kg. Patients who were transfusion-dependent displayed a positive clinical and/or hematologic response to the combination therapy.

135.summary: This project aims to investigate 'The minimum diagnostic requirements for patients presenting to primary care with suspected venous ulcers.' In order to do this, the investigators intend to run a series of questionnaires with primary care services, vascular science services, and perform some cost effectiveness modelling on running diagnostic services in primary care and in secondary care settings. A one off questionnaire, designed in Qualtrics, will be sent out to primary care practitioners via social media and email contacts. This will be aimed at establishing their current role and any guidelines they follow with regards to the diagnosis and management of venous leg ulcers in primary care, and to determine their opinion of what this patient pathway should involve. A Delphi consensus will be carried out amongst vascular scientists across the UK to determine current and streamline future practice in diagnostics for patients with venous leg ulcers. The consensus will be achieved when there is ≥ 70% agreement. Cost effectiveness modelling will be carried out on two different scenarios of managing this cohort of patients, one in primary care and one in secondary care settings. Descriptive statistics will be performed on the results.

136.summary:
The goal of this clinical trial is to use a novel virtual reality intervention to test for efficacy in reducing stimulant use and increasing abstinence, with concomitant increases in future self-identification, future time perspective, and delay-of-reward, in early recovering stimulant use disorder (StUD) persons. The main question[s] this trial aims to answer are:
Will the Virtual Reality (VR) intervention decrease the number of stimulant use days?
Will the VR intervention produce longer abstinence periods during follow-up visits?
Will the VR intervention increase stimulant drug abstinence rates?
Will the VR intervention increase future self-identification?
Will the VR intervention increase self-reported future time perspective?
Will the VR intervention increase preference for delayed rewards in a laboratory delay discounting task on the study day?
Will the VR intervention produce gains in the behavioral effects of future self-identification, future time perspective, and delayed rewards at the 30-day and 6-month follow-ups?
Researchers will compare the experimental and control groups to see if there are differences in the results for the questions outlined above.

<|assistant|> Background: Future time perspective is a key aspect of prospective thinking, which is associated with substance use disorders (SUDs). Prospective thinking relies upon future self-concept, which includes beliefs about a future version of the self. Deficits in future time perspective and future self-concept in individuals with SUDs have been linked to drug seeking and reuse. We aim to enhance future time perspective and future self-concept in individuals with SUDs through Virtual Reality (VR) exposure. Methods: This study is an experimental, randomized, waitlist-controlled, two-sample parallel assignment study. Participants are 18 years of age and above with outpatient psychotropic medication for SUD. Participants are randomized to one of two parallel groups. The experimental group is allocated to the Virtual Reality Avatar experience (first week) + Treatment as Usual (TaU) in which participants are asked to reflect on a future time-perspective goal. The control group is allocated to TaU alone. Both groups have one in-person session where participants are placed in a Virtual Reality environment (VR Park) for approximately 10 minutes, either with or without an avatar. This avatar resembles the participant in clothing and style but is modified to reflect an avatar who is more physically active and exercising. Both groups have follow-up sessions at 30 days and 6 months. Primary and secondary outcomes include self-reported use of drugs, lengths of abstinence, and time/time horizon related measures. Potential Implications: The current study is the first known study to examine the effect of VR exposure upon future time perspective in individuals with SUDs seeking treatment. If effective, the current study has the potential to inform the development of VR exposure-based interventions, especially in low-threshold settings. 138.summary: Despite progress in chemotherapy, targeted therapy and immunotherapy, allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (allo-SCT) is still the only curative procedure for some hematological malignancies. The probability of finding a matched sibling donor (MSD) is estimated under the classical 30%, because of the age of patients and their relatives, and a matched unrelated donor (MUD) can take time to identify. Currently in France, 25% of the allo-SCT are performed with an haplo-identical related donor. The Baltimore group developed an approach using haploidentical related donors, RIC, T-replete bone marrow and post-transplant high dose cyclophosphamide (PTCy) in patients with advanced hematological malignancies. PTCy has shown to eradicate alloreactive donor and host T-cells, activated by respective antigens, thereby reducing the incidence of graft versus host disease (GvHD) but delaying hematopoietic recovery. Therefore, the main source of graft is peripheral blood stem cells (PBSC) mobilized by G-CSF in France. Unfortunately, with PBSC we observe a higher cumulative incidence of GvHD (around 50%) and a higher toxicity-related mortality (TRM), especially for recipients >50 years old. The co-transplantation of Mesenchymal Stem Cells (MSC) at the time of transplantation has previously shown a double interest in GvHD immunomodulation and hematopoiesis support. Pre-clinical studies (in mice) have shown that mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) from Wharton's Jelly reduce the incidence of GvHD when the infusions are weekly repeated. We propose a phase I clinical trial to find the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of a weekly infusion of WJ-MSC administered as GvHD prophylaxis and as a support for a faster hematological reconstitution after haplo-identical allo-SCT.
138.model_output:
<|assistant|>
The study is divided into 3 parts. The first part is a cohort of a limited number of patients (maximum n+2) given a dose of 1x10e6 WJ-MSC/kg. The second part starts by the administration of 3 weekly injections of 1.5x10e6/kg as maximum tolerated dose (MTD) in patients with a high risk of graft failaure. Finally in the third part, the aim is to define the maximum tolerated dose in all haplo-identical SCT for adult patient with hematologic malignancies or hematologic syndrome. The first part includes 7 patients enrolled in a dose escalation of Wharton Jelly Mesenchymal Stromal Cells (1x10e6/kg, MTD 1.5x10e6/kg) using a modified "three plus three" rule. The two dose levels will be tested on 6 patients.
The second part includes 9 patients in HSCT from a haplo-identical donor with a MUD MRD of less than 1%. The patients will receive Wharton Jelly mesenchymal stromal cells (WG-MSC) at a dose of 1.5x10e6/Kg/infusion repeated 3 times within a maximum of 2 weeks.
The third part includes 42 patients in HSCT from a haplo-identical donor with a MUD MRD of less than 1%. The infusion schedule and number of injection will be adapted according with the number of patients recruited in the second part after the delineation of the MTD.

139.summary:
In this study, the investigators will deploy a software-based clinical decision support tool (eCARTv5) into the electronic health record (EHR) workflow of multiple hospital wards. eCART's algorithm is designed to analyze real-time EHR data, such as vitals and laboratory results, to identify which patients are at increased risk for clinical deterioration. The algorithm specifically predicts imminent death or the need for intensive care unit (ICU) transfer. Within the eCART interface, clinical teams are then directed toward standardized guidance to determine next steps in care for elevated-risk patients.
The investigators hypothesize that implementing such a tool will be associated with a decrease in ventilator utilization, length of stay, and mortality for high-risk hospitalized adults.
139.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Clinical deterioration occurs in approximately 5% of hospitalized adults in the United States and is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. The most severe deterioration is most often associated with critical illness, an outcome that is heralded by the gradual development of physiologic abnormalities in multiple organ systems. Early identification of patients at risk for critical illness followed by intervention and optimization can reduce the risk of adverse outcomes. Although numerous early warning scores (EWSs, such as Modified Early Warning Score (MEWS)) have been developed, the sensitivity and specificity of EWSs is far from perfect. Machine learning algorithms, which identify patterns in big data, improve accuracy but only achieve high clinical accuracy if fully integrated into hospital workflows. This study examines performance parameters of a more sophisticated machine learning algorithm (ecarter) at a single academic medical center and seeks to measure its impact on patient care at 4 healthcare organizations (HOs) using a randomized controlled design. The primary outcome measure is to determine whether eCART reduces mortality for high-risk hospitalized patients at participating HOs. Secondary outcome measures include reduction in ventilator utilization, length of stay, and the proportion of ICU- and ventilator-free days for elevated risk patients. This trial involves the development of an artificial intelligence model for screening hospitalized patients and standardization of care of these patients based on clinical pathways. We expect that rapid identification and management of acutely ill hospitalized patients will improve clinical outcomes and resource allocation.

140.summary: The objective of this treatment study is to develop and test an augmentation therapy in conjunction with maternal psychiatric treatment that targets the fathers' support of the mothers' mental health and contributions to the family environment to reduce maternal stress. The African-American Social Support Effectiveness Treatment-Partners alleviating Perinatal Depression (ASSET-PPD) intervention will be delivered to fathers in an individual setting to target the context in which a mother lives to expand her support beyond the direct reach of her treatment professional. This study provides skills and training to fathers who have a partner with prenatal depression. The aim is to reduce maternal depression during the perinatal period and improve the family environment for the infant.
140.model_output:
<|assistant|>
African-American (AA) mothers have a higher risk of perinatal depression than Caucasian women, primarily attributing to high environmental stressors. Pregnant or postpartum AA women also have poor mental healthcare utilization and compliance with psychiatric treatment, contributing to poor clinical outcomes. In addition, AA fathers have a critical role in reducing the mother's emotional distress and environmental stress. This study will address some of these shortcomings by using fathers as an untapped resource to reduce the mother's environmental stress and encourage healthy maternal behaviors. The proposed study aims to design and implement a culturally-based and empirically-tailored intervention to target the AA father's mental health literacy, psychoeducation, and communication skills with the AA mother to reduce maternal depression symptoms during the prenatal to postpartum period. Also, this study will enhance the father's parenting and the mother-father-infant relationship through targeted skills and support. Twenty-five dyads of pregnant or postpartum dyads aged 18 or older, in committed relationships or not, will be randomized into the ASSET-PPD (African-American Social Support Effectiveness Treatment-Partners Alleviating Perinatal Depression) or the No Treatment comparison groups. The ASSET-PPD intervention will be designed to have 4 active modules that address the key factors to reduce maternal stress during the prenatal and postpartum period. The modules will be individual sessions constructed to provide training, information, and behavioral assignments to increase fathers' understanding of depression- and anxiety-provoking situations, and to create a communication and a parenting plan that promotes an equal division of parenting responsibilities before the birth of the infant. The primary outcome will be maternal depression, assessed using the Inventory of Depressive Symptoms-Self-Rated (IDS-SR16). Secondary outcomes will include infant attachment, breastfeeding experience, and parent-infant interactions. This study will be effective in supporting women with PND and will have a high probability of improving the mental health outcomes and parental-child health of the children of AA women, potentially making an impact on future social policies concerning AA women's mental health.

-----------------
Parents will be 18 years of age or older. Parents are eligible for the study if the woman is in the 2nd trimester, she is receiving psychiatric treatment for depression with a score of 11 or greater on the Inventory of Depressive Symptoms-Self-Rated (IDS-SR16), which indicates clinically significant symptoms, and the mother is African-American Parents do not need to be romantic partners to be eligible. Infants (0-6 months) are included in the study to examine the parent-infant interactions Exclusion Criteria: The parents will be excluded if: There is report of ongoing physical or sexual abuse They have plans to terminate the pregnancy The woman is showing symptoms of hypomania/mania, psychosis, or substance use in the past 12 months Father will be excluded if he: Has symptoms of psychosis in the past 12 months Has below 6th grade education Has difficulty focusing on 1 hour of instruction

142.summary:
The goal of this clinical trial is to test the effectiveness of fault-detection algorithms in detecting malfunctioning of the insulin infusion system in an artificial pancreas (also known as Automated Insulin Delivery system) for type 1 diabetes.
The main questions it aims to answer is:
Are the proposed algorithms effective in detecting insulin suspension? Effectiveness accounts for both high sensitivity (i.e. the fraction of suspension correctly detected) and low false alarm rate.
The study has three phases:
free-living artificial pancreas data collection,
in-patient induction of hyperglycemia (mimicking an insulin pump malfunction),
retrospective analysis of the collected data to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms in detecting insulin suspension.
142.model_output:
<|assistant|>
This study is designed as a retrospective data analysis of a database of controlled malfunction simulation in subjects with type 1 diabetes receiving automated insulin delivery (AID). The current clinical practice is currently performed by recording the time series of glucose, insulin, and food intake data produced by the patients' AID, without any a priori information about the onset of the malfunction itself. To address this limitation, the investigators developed a control algorithm to detect episodes of insulin pump malfunction, based on the comparison between pre- and post-malfunction data-sets, the latter characterized by a significant increase in glycemia. However, a validation of this algorithm in real clinical practice, with a sufficient number of patients, may confirm the actual effectiveness and safety of this detection system. The use of a retrospective analysis, as currently conducted in the clinical practice, would permit the collection of a large amount of high-quality data, with a precise characterization of the malfunctions, as previously described. These data could support further validation in a prospective study. In these circumstances, it is necessary to assess the sensitivity of a number of detection techniques, in order to estimate the probability that a suspected insulin pump malfunction corresponds to a true positive event. The investigators propose the following study objectives: 1) Assess the sensitivity of the existing algorithms for the detection of insulin pump malfunctions (currently used in clinical practice) in 20 patients; 2) Analyze the ability of the proposed algorithms to detect malfunctions when the glycemic excursion is milder than what was simulated in this study, in 15 additional patients. The investigators expect that a sensitivity of 100% in detecting insulin suspension will be achieved, when the glycemic excursion following malfunction is higher than a defined threshold. As a secondary objective, the investigators will assess the safety of the study procedures, in terms of the risk of hyperglycemia and other side effects or complications. The study results may lead to optimization and improvement of the glycemic control, and to avoid the occurrence of the most serious risks associated with malfunctions. The study will be conducted on a population of 20 patients with type 1 diabetes, under insulin pump treatment and using continuous glucose monitoring sensors. The study will be conducted in two phases: - Phase 1: collection of free living data - Phase 2: malfunction simulation (data analysis after the experiment). The patients enrolled will be required to visit the study center at least twice: one baseline visit to activate the artificial pancreas and collect baseline data, and one visit to perform the malfunction simulation. Based on the experience gained during phase 1, the malfunction simulation procedure aims at inducing different durations and severity of hyperglycemia, by means of controlled insulin suspension. The study team will assist the patient in the restoration of normoglycemia before sending the patient back home. To account for the variability of the response to insulin suspension, subjects with type 1 diabetes and AID therapy are planned for enrollment, as the response to the same malfunction may vary according to the patient, insulin dose, and other factors such as meal intake, exercise, and illness. These factors will be carefully recorded by means of standardized questionnaires to be filled by each participant during the study visits.
The novelty of this approach is in the control of the experimental insulin suspension events, performed under medical supervision in a controlled and documented setting. The data collected in this study will be the only human trial dataset where malfunctions have been induced with precisely defined characteristics. By analyzing data generated by these experiments, it will be possible to develop accurate algorithms for detecting malfunctions and minimize the risk of missing important events because of lack of data. As a result, the patients will benefit of a more reliable system for insulin infusion and monitoring, with a reduced risk of critical and dangerous consequences.
