144.summary:
The goal of this clinical trial is to assess the (cost-)effectiveness of a personalised risk assessment tool (PERSARC) to increase patients' knowledge about risks and benefits of treatment options and to reduce decisional conflict in comparison with usual care in high-grade extremity Soft-Tissue Sarcoma-patients.
High-grade (2-3) extremity Soft-Tissue Sarcoma patients (>= 18 years) will either receive standard care (control group) or care with the use of PERSARC; i.e. PERSARC will be used in multidisciplinary tumour boards to guide treatment advice and in consultation in which the oncological/orthopaedic surgeon informs the patient about his/her diagnoses and discusses the benefits and harms of all relevant treatment options (intervention group)
144.model_output:
<|assistant|>
To assess whether the use of the personalized risk assessment tool (PERSARC) is (cost)effective in reducing decisional conflict and increasing informed choices in high-grade extremity Soft-tissue Sarcoma patients compared to usual care (co-primary outcomes). In addition, we aim to assess in a process evaluation (a) the involvement of patients in decision-making (b) the extent and way PERSARC is used by patients and professionals, and (c) how satisfied patients and professionals were with the use of PERSARC. Study design: To assess the (cost)effectiveness of PERSARC in treatment decisions of high-grade extremity Soft-tissue Sarcoma-patients, a parallel cluster randomized trial will be conducted in the 6 Dutch hospitals that are Soft-tissue sarcoma expertise centers. Hospitals will be randomized between standard care (control condition) or care with the use of PERSARC (intervention). Outcomes will be assessed within one week after treatment decision has been made (T1), and after 3, 6 and 12 months after the treatment decision has been made (T2, T3, T4) in at least 120 patients. See main study parameters/endpoints for a description of the outcomes that will be measured at these time points. Actual use of PERSARC, satisfaction with/added value of PERSARC and barriers and facilitators for the integration of PERSARC in treatment decision-making processes during patient-clinician encounters will be measured in a process evaluation using questionnaires, interviews, and audio-recording/observation of consultations. Study population: Patients (>= 18 years) with primarily diagnosed (histologically confirmed) grade 2-3 extremity Soft-Tissue Sarcoma, who do not have a treatment plan yet and will be treated with curative intent. Patients with sarcoma subtypes or treatment options other than those mentioned in PERSARC are unable to participate. Furthermore, patients need to be Dutch fluency and literacy and mentally competent. Intervention (if applicable): High-grade extremity Soft-tissue Sarcoma patients will either receive standard care (control group) or care with the use of PERSARC; i.e. PERSARC will be used in multidisciplinary tumour boards to guide treatment advice and in consultation in which the oncological/orthopaedic surgeon informs the patient about his/her diagnoses and discusses the benefits and harms of all relevant treatment options (intervention group). Main study parameters/endpoints: The co-primary outcomes are decisional conflict (Decisional Conflict Scale(DCS) (T1) and informed choice (T1), combined outcome incorporating knowledge (self-developed questionnaire), attitudes concerning trade-offs between quality and length of life (QQ_Questionnaire, see below) and treatment decision (T1). Informed choice is a combined outcome incorporating knowledge (self-developed questionnaire), attitudes concerning trade-offs between quality and length of life (QQ_Questionnaire, see below) and treatment decision (T1) Secondary outcomes, include regret (Decision_Regret_Scale) (T3, T4), worry (Cancer_Worry_scale) (T1, T2, T3, T4), involvement in decision-making according to patients (SDM-Q-9) (T1), patient reported outcome using the Patient Reported Outcome Measures (PROMIS Global health) (T1, 2, 3, 4), (PROMIS physical function) (T1, 2, 3, 4), utilities for the cost-effectiveness analysis (EQ-5D-5L) (T1, T2, T3, T4), health care cost (iMCQ) (T2, T3, T4) and absenteeism/presenteeism from paid work (T2, T3, T4).

145.summary: In this cross sectional epidemiological study, we aimed to report the prevalence of early childhood caries (ECC) in children attending kindergartens in Jordan, and its associated risk factors. We also, aimed to determine the effectiveness of silver diamine fluoride as a caries control material and its acceptance among parents of children with ECC. Children (n=887) with mean age 4.64 ± 1.56 were examined. Among this sample there was a number of children (n=159) who were enrolled in a randomized controlled trial to study silver diamine fluoride efficacy in caries control. The sample consisted of two groups; the study group (children who received single spot application of 38% SDF) and control group (children who were examined only).

Early Childhood Caries (ECC) is a public health challenge in both low and high mortality countries including the Kingdom of Jordan. The prevalence rates of caries in children attending early education and care centers in Jordan are reported to be 47- 90% in children of the age group 2 - 6 years. The objectives of this study is to report the prevalence of ECC and its associated risk factors in Jordanian children, and to determine the effectiveness of Silver Diamine Fluoride application on caries prevention for children aged from 3 - 5 years with ECC.
The study will involve children aged from 3 - 5 years who will have full mouth dental examination and questionnaires for risk factors, oral health related habits, maternal oral health, children's age and sex. The children will be divided into two groups; study group (received SDF) and control group (no intervention) at a ratio of 1:1 to determine any statistical significance of the treatment in terms of caries prevention. The participants will be asked to fill data related to the approval/disapproval of application of SDF and follow up at 1 year after application for any changes.
The results of this study would highlight the effectiveness of SDF as a preventive agent for early childhood caries, and also provide baseline data about the ECC prevalence, risk factors, and oral health related practices in Jordan. It may have impact in decision making for the dental profession to help support the inclusion of SDF as part of evidence-based protocol of caries management in children.

146.summary:
The main purpose of this study is to learn about the effectiveness of Pfizer's ABRYSVO vaccine. This vaccine helps to prevent infections caused by Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV). RSV is a virus that can cause infections in the airways. These symptoms can be cold-like symptoms, but in some cases can lead to severe symptoms or hospitalization.
This study uses only healthcare data that are already collected from routine visits to healthcare providers. This means that participants will not be actively enrolled in the study and there are no study treatments. The study will look at data for about two years. This study will look at patient information from:
Adults ages 60 years and older
Are eligible to receive the ABRYSVO vaccination
146.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Background: Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) infections are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in older adults. Pfizer's ABRYSVO is a recently-available RSV vaccine that is intended to prevent disease caused by RSV.
Previous trials of ABRYSVO showed the vaccine's effectiveness at preventing RSV infection in older adults living in long-term care facilities (LTCF) and in older adults with cardiac/respiratory conditions. The overall effectiveness was higher in the LTCF trial versus the cardiac/respiratory trial. The LTCF trial also identified a potential suboptimal VE among participants who previously were infected with one or both RSV subgroups.
The Kaiser Permanente Southern California (KPSC) Vaccine Study Program (VSP) maintains significant resources for the evaluation of influenza and RSV vaccines in a population-based health care delivery system, providing access to electronic medical record data for more than 4.5 million individuals.
Objective: This two-year study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of RSV vaccine in preventing lower respiratory tract infections (LRTI) among older adults in KPSC, who are eligible for RSV vaccination per ACIP guidelines. Secondary objectives include evaluating the vaccine's effectiveness in preventing severe events (e.g., hospitalization or mortality) in the selected patient populations. This study will evaluate effectiveness as follows:
Primary Outcome Measure: Test Negative Design (TND) 1. Vaccine Effectiveness (VE) calculated as 1 minus the odds ratio (OR) comparing the odds of being vaccinated with ABRYSVO for RSV-related hospitalized LRTI cases and controls, multiplied by 100%.
Administrative and Biologic Exemptions: 27.8% ABRYSVO coverage rates among the entire group at risk for vaccine preventable disease, as well as among those hospitalized and/or ED visited with a respiratory infection, are likely, given Kaiser Permanente's prior vaccine efforts. To address expected noncompliance with the 24-month exclusion window among those who are unvaccinated, we plan to include a 12-month control group, for VE estimation at this specific timepoint.

Eligibility: All Kaiser Permanente Southern California members born on or before 31-12-1935, regardless of sex or residence.
Design: Retrospective cohort study including 2 components: 1) TND, in which cases were identified using inpatient and certain outpatient medical claims and remnant respiratory specimens, to assess RSV-related hospitalizations, among which participants may have received prior vaccination or had prior documented RSV infection; and 2) population-based cohort including all KPSC patients at risk for RSV vaccine preventable, and nonpreventable, ARI/LRTI, as well as mortality.

Statistical Analysis: For the cohort study, we will estimate Incidence Rates (IRs) and related rate differences for all ARI and LRTI outcomes. We will also estimate VE using modified Poisson regression, adjusted for covariates including: 1) comorbid conditions, 2) RSV subgroup, 3) severity, and 4) age to describe the effectiveness of ABRYSVO against all-cause LRTI and ARI.

This study will have the potential to address important unanswered questions regarding the effectiveness of RSV vaccine in preventing lower respiratory tract infection in the KPSC population. The cohort study component will provide insights into the effectiveness of the vaccination against other ARI and LRTI outcomes, as well as provide a comprehensive understanding of the vaccine's effects in the general population. This study will further clarify the risk/benefit profiles to assist decision-making for RSV vaccine.

147.summary:
This is a prospective, observational, non-randomized, multicenter, international post-market clinical follow-up investigation aiming to confirm the performance and safety of the bone substitute b.Bone after implantation in patients in isolation or as a graft expander requiring bone grafting for the treatment of surgically created bone defects or bone defects/voids resulting from traumatic injury to promote healing in the pelvis, upper and lower extremities. Patients enrolled in this clinical investigation will undergo orthopaedic surgery with b.Bone as recommended by the specialist and according to orthopaedic standard procedures. Patients will be evaluated preoperatively and at different time points after the surgery according to the standard practice of the sites. The expected schedule is at month 3, month 6 and month 12. Patients who require longer follow-up and could be subjected to metalwork removal will be evaluated up to 24 months. All safety data will be collected from patient inclusion to the end of the clinical investigation.
All study visits will coincide with any of the patient's routine clinical visits, without interfering with the investigator's clinical duties.
It is planned to enroll 135-193 patients from approximately 15 EU and UK sites.

148.summary:
Acute-on-chronic liver failure (ACLF) is a syndrome associated with a high short- term mortality. Early identification of patients at high risk is important to determine emergency for transplantation and prioritize the need for intensive care unit. Unbalanced systemic inflammatory response is closely associated with mortality in ACLF patients. This systemic inflammatory response in ACLF increases liver and splenic stiffness stiffnes, which can be detected by transient elastography.
Very few studies have been done in past evaluating liver and splenic stiffness as prognostic tool in patients of ACLF. These studies have taken only single value of liver and splenic stiffness as prognostic tool. No follow up study have yet been done assessing acute change in liver and splenic stiffness in ACLF. In this study, we hypothesize that acute change in liver and splenic stiffness at 7th & 14 th day predicts outcome in ACLF patients. With this study, we aim to evaluate whether acute changes in liver and splenic stiffness at 7th & 14th day predicts outcome at 3 months in patients of ACLF.
148.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Acute on chronic liver failure (ACLF) is characterized by recent worsening of liver disease accompanied by acute organ failure (AOF) in a patient with chronic liver disease of any etiology. It often presents early on as an undifferentiated form of acute illness in a patient with chronic liver disease. Early detection and appropriate treatment may be life-saving. Liver transplantation is currently the best treatment for patients of ACLF. There is no consensus regarding the criteria of ACLF to select the patients for liver transplantation. Liver failure is characterized by the rapid progression of jaundice and acute deterioration in renal function and coagulopathy with or without ascites and gastrointestinal bleeding. It is commonly caused by endotoxemia followed by cytokines, as well as activation of the coagulation system.
The investigators wish to assess three different biomarkers, and find the biomarkers for accurate prognosis in the ACLF patients. ACLF patients have been considered for liver transplantation, which has shown good survival results. These patients will have three different biomarkers, fibroscan, TNF-alpha levels and CBC with PLR, NLR, SPL. They will be evaluated during the period of treatment for ACLF, i.e., 90 days and the investigators wish to select the patients for liver transplantation.
The investigators want to study the role of change in liver and splenic stiffness at day 7 (early on) of the disease by fibroscan in ACLF patients with acute change in baseline liver and splenic stiffness in predicting survival in ACLF patients.
The investigators also want to study the role of baseline liver and splenic stiffness with baseline characteristics of disease, etiology, baseline level of systemic and splanchnic pro-inflammatory markers, and pattern of organ failures in predicting survival in ACLF patients.

149.summary:
STUDY QUESTION: Does the depth of injection of onabotulinumtoxinA neurotoxin in the glabellar complex affect efficacy of the BoTN for the improvement of glabellar frown lines? STUDY AIM
Primary objective: Compare the efficacy of onabotulinumtoxinA neurotoxin injected at the depth of 2mm vs 4mm for the improvement of glabellar lines
Secondary objective: Determine any adverse effects of onabotulinumtoxinA neurotoxin injected at the depth of 2mm vs 4mm
RATIONALE FOR THE PROJECT:
Although the use of BoTN for treatment of glabellar lines has long been established as safe and effective, the optimal depth of injection has not been established. Our project hopes to establish the optimal depth of injection for onabotulinumtoxinA neurotoxin for maximal improvement of glabellar lines with minimal adverse effects
149.model_output:
<|assistant|>
The efficacy and safety of the use of botulinum toxin type A in the treatment of facial wrinkles has been well established by many studies. Botulinum toxin is a safe and effective treatment for facial wrinkles and has a high patient satisfaction rate. Botulinum toxin acts by blocking the release of acetylcholine from the neuromuscular junction and thereby temporarily paralyzing the muscles responsible for facial movement and expression. In patients with hyperkinetic wrinkles, most notably the glabellar complex or frown lines in the region of the procerus and corrugator supercilii muscles, the toxin causes selective, temporary paralysis of the muscles responsible for producing frown lines. With the increasing usage of botulinum toxin, many studies have validated its efficacy and safety. However, botulinum toxin is prone to variable responses from a dose of 20U to 50U depending on several factors such as the muscle strength, thickness of the muscle and muscle area to be treated, as well as the injector's experience and skill. Variability in injection technique and individual patient response to botulinum toxin can lead to complications, such as incomplete inhibition and/or over-inhibition. Furthermore, the efficacy and safety of the BoTN varies depending on the injection depth. The depth can vary between injectors and can lead to adverse effects such as overdose, under-dose, intravascular injection, and bruising. Additionally, there is no in vivo data on the optimal injection depth of botulinum toxin in the glabellar complex. In this study, the investigators aim to establish an injection depth map for botulinum toxin type A, either at the Superficial Dermis Depth or Intramuscular Depth for the treatment of glabellar wrinkles. With this study the investigators also aim to determine any adverse effects associated with both treatment arms. The objective of this study is to determine the optimal depth of botulinum toxin injections to treat glabellar lines in the glabellar complex.

Inclusion Criteria:
Patient age 18 and older
Patient able to understand requirements of the study and risks involved
Patient able to sign a consent form

150.summary:
Breast cancer is the number one cancer in women worldwide, with 58,500 new cases in metropolitan France in 2018. The announcement of the cancer, the treatment methods and their side effects can generate unpleasant emotions, such as fear, for example, and the resources for coping with them differ according to the patient. Coming to the hospital as an outpatient for chemotherapy is in itself a source of anxiety.
The use of music in the treatment process is a therapy that can help patients to reduce the intensity of their unpleasant emotions. Active music therapy involves the patient playing an instrument, including voice and body movement in rhythm, without requiring any musical skills. The presence of a qualified music therapy professional is essential, particularly in the reception of the emotions that may be generated during the sessions. These sessions can be collective or individual. In breast cancer, music therapy has been shown to be effective in reducing pain, anxiety, depressive symptoms and length of hospitalisation in patients undergoing mastectomy.

151.summary: Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) from a human leukocyte antigen (HLA) -matched donor is an effective option for severe aplastic anemia (SAA), but there is no standardized and recommended conditioning regimen. The occurrence of mixed chimerism after transplantation is associated with secondary graft failure and poor failure-free survival. Previous studies have shown that Fludarabine (Flu)/ Cyclophosphamide (Cy)/ antithymocyte globulin (antithymocyte globulin), ATG) and Cy/ATG conditioning regimens had higher rates of mixed chimerism and poorer failure-free survival. A small cohort study has suggested that adding busulfan to Flu/Cy/ATG or Cy/ATG can reduce the incidence of mixed chimerism and improve failure-free survival. This study was a prospective, multicenter, randomized controlled trial to compare the efficacy and safety of different conditioning regimens in the treatment of severe aplastic anemia (SAA) after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) from HLA-identical sibling or unrelated donor.
151.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is the only treatment that can achieve long-term disease control in severe aplastic anemia (SAA), but it has a 20-30% mortality rate. Graft failure and relapse remain the major causes of death. Recently, non-myeloablative allogeneic transplantation has been proven to have much lower treatment-related mortality. A number of clinical trials showed that the outcome of HSCT using non-T cell depleted alografts was much better than T-cell depleted alografts. However, the incidence of graft versus host disease (GVHD) was also very high. In China, the incidence of GVHD in SAA is 70% to 80% and most of the patients required systemic steroid therapy. Non-myeloablative transplantation has also been used in unrelated cord blood transplantation. The outcome was good especially for unrelated cord blood transplantation for juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia. However, the outcome in adult patients with acute leukemia was not satisfactory. In the recent years, several conditioning regimens have been used in unrelated cord blood transplantation. Several reports showed that busulfan combined with fludarabine and cyclophosphamide (Bu/Flu/Cy) or Cy/ATG conditioning regimens also have a good outcome. However, these conditioning regimens were associated with cardiac toxicity and the incidence of graft failure was relatively high. It has been proposed that the regimens may be changed to avoid the cardiac toxicity of these conditioning. Our experience showed that the incidence of GVHD in this population is relatively high and the management of GVHD in this population was very difficult. Therefore, we propose to conduct a prospective, multicenter, randomized controlled study. The intervention of different conditioning regimens will be evaluated in patients who underwent HSCT from matched sibling or matched unrelated donors.
Primary Objective:
1 To compare the non-relapse mortality of two different conditioning regimens by transplanting HLA matched sibling or unrelated donors in SAA patients.

Secondary Objective:
1 To compare the overall survival and failure-free survival of two different conditioning regimens by transplanting HLA matched sibling or unrelated donors in SAA patients.
2 To evaluate the incidence of GVHD, engraftment, graft vs. leukemia effect and regimen related toxicity of two different conditioning regimens by transplanting HLA matched sibling or unrelated donors in SAA patients.
3 To evaluate the incidence of CMV and EBV reactivation of two different conditioning regimens by transplanting HLA matched sibling or unrelated donors in SAA patients.

Sample size: 64 patients will be recruited to evaluate non-relapse mortality. With an incidence of 30% event under the busulfan included conditioning, a sample size of 64 will have 80% power (with α = 0.05) to detect a 10-point reduction in event rate. The estimated sample size when comparing failure-free survival is more than 130.

152.summary:
This is an exploratory, single group, Phase 1, 1-arm study to assess treatment with fitusiran prophylaxis after switching from emicizumab prophylaxis.
This study aims to evaluate the safety and tolerability of switching to fitusiran after a transition period from the last dose of emicizumab. The study will be conducted in male participants with severe hemophilia A, with or without inhibitors, aged ≥18 years, who were previously receiving emicizumab prophylaxis.
Study details include:
The study duration will be up to approximately 28 months:
There will be an approximately 2-month screening period.
There will be a transition period before fitusiran treatment starts (pre-fitusiran treatment period)
The fitusiran treatment duration will be up to 18-months (fitusiran treatment period)
The antithrombin (AT) follow-up (FU) period will be up to 6 months after the last dose of fitusiran (during which the AT activity level will be monitored at approximately monthly intervals following the final fitusiran dose until AT activity levels return to at least 60%).
The study site visits are scheduled at monthly/ every 2 months intervals of 28 days (4 weeks) / 56 days (8 weeks), respectively, during the fitusiran treatment period.

<|assistant|>
This is a study to test a medicine (Fitusiran) for preventing bleeds in people with severe hemophilia A who previously received preventive treatment with Emicizumab. The study includes participants with bleeding disorder caused by severe hemophilia A, irrespective of whether or not they had inhibitors. Participants will receive Fitusiran prophylaxis once every 2 months or once monthly by subcutaneous injections for 18 months. Up to 100 participants will be enrolled.

153.summary: The translation and cultural adaptation process of the English version of PDQ will be performed based on international guidelines. Subsequently, patients with neuropathic and nociceptive pain based on clinician's diagnoses will be recruited to complete three-type numeric rating scale (NRS) of pain followed by PDQ-M and SF-36 questionnaire. Patients' socio-demographic data and clinical characteristics will be reported using frequency for categorical variables and mean with standard deviation for continuous variables. Normality will be assessed using Shapiro Wilk test and histograms for continuous variables. Data will be compared between groups using chi-square test (for categorical variables) and t-test or Mann-Whitney's U test (for continuous variables). Suitability of PDQ-M data for factor analysis will be verified using the Bartlett's test of sphericity and the Kaiser-Mayer-Olkin (KMO) measure of sampling adequacy. Parallel analysis will performed to obtain the suitable factors. Construct validity will be investigated by exploratory factorial analysis (EFA) with varimax rotation. A factor loading of >0.40 will be used to determine the items for each factor. The internal consistency of the questionnaire will be assessed using Cronbach's alpha test. A p value of <0.05 is taken as statistically significant.
153.model_output:
<|assistant|>
The aim of the study is to test the reliability and validity of the Malay PainDETECT Questionnaire (PDQ-M) in patients with both neuropathic and nociceptive pain. There are 7 items in the PDQ-M questionnaire, which is derived from the original PDQ, a nine-item questionnaire. There are no previous studies using painDETECT in patients with pain in Malaysia. Therefore, it has been used in other countries including Germany, The Netherlands, China to name a few. The purpose of this study is to translate the original German version of PDQ to Malay to produce a Malay version of the questionnaire (PDQ-M) and to assess the test-retest reliability as well as the criterion validity.

154.summary: A lot of physical and social effects of exercise programs and daily physical education have already been proven for stroke patients after discharge. However, stroke patients have shown a passive attitude in participating in physical education or exercise programs for life, and the local community lacked appropriate guidelines or experience in guiding exercise and physical education for stroke patients, so they had a burden on instructing exercise. In this study, an appropriate complex exercise program was established for patients after discharge through analysis of domestic and foreign research data to provide an environment and opportunity to exercise in the community, and based on the results, stroke patients actively exercise in the community in the future. The goal is to provide a basis for doing so.
154.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Background: Stroke patients are at high risk of cardiovascular diseases and functional limitations.
Study Design and Methods: A total of 40 stroke patients, aged over 30 were randomly divided into the two groups, the non-exercise group and the exercise group. Both groups followed the same rehabilitation program at the rehabilitation hospital. The experimental group had 2 exercise classes for 6 weeks, and the other group did not have specific exercise classes other than the rehabilitation program. All patients were evaluated for physical abilities and activities of daily living before and after the program.
Results: The exercise group showed significantly better results in physical abilities than the non-exercise group, such as the 6-minute walk test, the Berg balance scale, and muscle strength. It also showed lower disability and depression scores and more physical activity. The difference was statistically significant (p < 0.05).
Conclusion: These results showed that the community-based complex exercise program could be a new option for stroke patients in rehabilitation, improving physical abilities and daily activities.

155.summary:
Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a progressive, irreversible neurological disorder and is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly population. Clinical symptoms of the disease may begin with occasional forgetfulness such as misplacement of items, forgetting important dates or events, and may progress to noticeable memory loss, increased confusion and agitation, and eventually, loss of independence and non-responsiveness. This study will assess how safe and effective ABBV-552 is in treating symptoms of early AD. Adverse events, change in disease activity, how ABBV-552 moves through body of participants and the body response to ABBV-552 will be assessed.
ABBV-552 is an investigational drug being developed for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease (AD). Study doctors put the participants in 1 of 4 groups (3 active dose groups and a placebo group), called treatment arms. Each group receives a different treatment. There is a 1 in 4 chance that participants will be assigned to placebo. Approximately 240 participants aged 50-90 years with mild AD will be enrolled in approximately 60 sites across the world.
Participants will receive oral ABBV-552 or placebo capsules once daily for 12 weeks and followed for 30 days after the last dose of study drug.
There may be higher treatment burden for participants in this trial compared to their standard of care. Participants will attend regular visits during the study at a hospital or clinic. The effect of the treatment will be checked by medical assessments, blood tests, checking for side effects and completing questionnaires.

156.summary:
Acute liver failure (ALF) is a potentially fatal complication of severe hepatic illness resulting from various causes. In a clinical setting, severe hepatic injury is usually recognized by the appearance of jaundice, encephalopathy and coagulopathy.
The term acute liver failure (ALF) is frequently applied as a generic expression to describe patients presenting with or developing an acute episode of liver dysfunction.
Cerebral edema is very common in patients with acute liver failure and encephalopathy.
Acute liver failure (ALF) has Less common aetiologies include viral hepatitis, drug-induced liver injury, pregnancy-induced liver failure and autoimmune hepatitis.
Survival for patients with ALF has steadily improved over the last few decades. Acute liver failure (ALF) is defined as sever acute liver injury with encephalopathy and impairment of synthetic function (INR ˃1.5) in a patient without pre-existing cirrhosis or liver disease.
Acute liver failure (ALF) and acute on chronic liver Failure (ACLF) are conditions frequently encountered in the ICU and are associated with high mortality.
156.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Introduction
-----------------
Acute liver failure (ALF) is the most severe form of acute liver disease, occurring mostly in adolescents and young adults. It often carries a grave prognosis and affects mainly the developed countries. The management of ALF is complicated by the large number of underlying etiologies and the complexity of the clinical picture, which represents a challenge to clinicians in the management of these cases.
Kidney diseases are known as causes of liver disease, however, kidney injury in the course of ALF is of much greater significance, because the liver is the primary site of endogenous biotransformation of drugs, and as a consequence, renal functions are very susceptible to liver failure. Kidney injury in ALF can develop by hepatorenal syndrome, nephrotic syndrome, acute kidney injury and rhabdomyolysis. ALF is associated with acute-on-chronic liver disease (ACLF), where some characteristics of both ALF and chronic liver disease coexist. ACLF is defined by the International Ascites Society as the presence of the following combinations of ascites, encephalopathy, or hepatic failure with bilirubin >3 mg/dL, along with other organ failure, including coagulopathy, hepatic encephalopathy, hepatorenal syndrome, or spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). Mortality rate of patients with ACLF was reported from 14% to 60% in other studies.
Due to lack of knowledge about the causes of ALF and ACLF, early diagnosis is vital for prognosis and recovery of patients. Early diagnosis of complications such as hepatorenal syndrome, nephrotic syndrome, and rhabdomyolysis is crucial, as these alter the course and outcome of ALF. Several risk factors that lead to ALF and ACLF have been identified in many studies.
In this study, ALF and ACLF cases are defined according to guidelines. ALF is defined as an acute deterioration of liver function in patients with previously normal liver function. It can be isolated liver failure, or it can evolve to ACLF by underlying liver cirrhosis that are detected after evaluation. ACLF is defined as evolving from chronic liver disease (CLD) or having a chronic progressive liver disease. CLD is defined as a known chronic liver disease for at least 6 months, with or without ascites, and with or without other organ failure.
Study goals
-----------------
Determination of risk factors leading to ALF and ACLF in a hospital setting. Study of the main causes of disease. Early determination of organ failure, and complications such as renal failure (hypotension or shock in the course of ALF), nephrotic syndrome, hepatorenal syndrome, and rhabdomyolysis. Assessment of mortality and short-term (1 week, 2 weeks) morbidity rates in patients with severe acute liver disease. Assessing hepatic and renal functions in individuals with ALF with regard to age and gender.
Methodology
-----------------
We aim to recruit at least 60 patients with ALF and 30 patients with ACLF fulfilling the specific criteria, who are admitted to intensive care units at National Liver Institute, Menoufia University. They will be assessed by history taking, physical examination, complete blood count, liver function tests. Clinical, radiological and echocardiographical assessments will be done along with special scores such as Child's Pugh, DF, C OFs scores and CLIF-SOFA score.
Inclusion criteria:
Patients admitted in the intensive care units in National Liver Institute at Menoufia University with the following criteria: Reduced conscious state (hepatic encephalopathy). Jaundice with abnormal liver function tests (laboratory parameters) such as amino acid transferase levels more than 25 times upper limit of normal, elevated serum ammonia levels (>89umol/l), low serum sodium levels (<135mEq/L) or prolongation of prothrombin time. Coagulopathy Inclusion criteria for acute on chronic liver disease (ACLD): presence of liver cirrhosis for at least 6 months with ascites, encephalopathy, or hepatic failure with bilirubin >3 mg/dL, along with other organ failure (coagulopathy, hepatic encephalopathy, hepatorenal syndrome, or spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (

157.summary: This study was planned to determine the predictive effects of impulsivity and coping skills on quality of life in patients with bipolar disorder. The sample of the study, which was carried out in a descriptive design, will consist of 80 patients who applied to Adıyaman Besni State Hospital Psychiatry Outpatient Clinic with a diagnosis of bipolar disorder according to Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-5 and who were in the euthymic period according to the doctor's control. It was planned to collect the data by applying the Personal Information Form prepared by the researchers, Brief Quality of Life in Bipolar Disorder, Barratt Impulsivity Scale -11 Short Form and Coping Attitudes Evaluation Scale. The data will be evaluated with descriptive statistics, Mann-Whitney U-test, Kruskal Wallis test, Pearson correlations and regression analyses using Statistical Package for the Social Sciences 22 software. Scale use and ethics committee permission were obtained from the responsible authors of the scales before the study.
157.model_output:
<|assistant|>
The goal of the study is to examine whether impulsivity and coping skills are associated with better (or worse) quality of life in people with bipolar disorder. People with bipolar disorder are at increased risk of suicide attempts compared with the general population. Therefore, it is important to identify factors that affect their quality of life. The study will take 12 weeks with two visits of approximately 15 minutes. If you are 18 years or older and suffer from bipolar disorder, you are eligible. The main aims of the study are:

1. To explore whether impulsivity and coping skills are associated with quality of life in people with bipolar disorder (i.e., to find out whether a high level of impulsivity reduces the quality of life of people with bipolar disorder).
2. To find out whether the participants' age and gender are associated with the quality of life.
3. To explore any other factors that may affect the quality of life. For example, other psychiatric conditions in addition to bipolar disorder (e.g., depression, anxiety etc.).
4. To find out whether there are any differences in the level of impulsivity and coping attitudes between participants with a history of suicide attempts and those without such a history.
5. To find out whether there are any differences in the level of impulsivity, coping attitudes and quality of life, depending on whether participants are currently in a manic phase of the disorder or in a 'normal mood' (i.e., neither manic nor depressed). The findings of this study may be useful for improving quality of life for those with bipolar disorder.

The risk to participants is no greater than when people with bipolar disorder receive usual care. There is no specific treatment involved in this study.

If you currently have bipolar disorder and are 18 years or older, you are welcome to join this research study. If 10 or more people with bipolar disorder are found to participate (and if they sign the consent form), they will be interviewed for approximately 15 minutes in total. Firstly, they will be requested to sign the consent form. Then, they will complete 3 self-report questionnaires: 1) Quality of life in bipolar disorder scale, 2) Barratt-Impulsivity-scale, and 3) the Coping Attitudes Questionnaire.

158.summary:
Dentists have recently preferred to use composite materials and restorative techniques that allow the use of simplified clinical protocols in order to reduce the time the patient spends in the dentist's chair and minimize technical sensitivity. Color selection in the clinic is a very sensitive process and is affected by environmental factors and operator-related variables. This has led to the development of single-color universal composite resins that aim to facilitate color selection. These materials have a universal opacity and several Vita shades and are recommended by manufacturers to be used in a single color layer that can match different tooth colors. In recent years, monochromatic universal composites have been developed that are supposed to be compatible with all Vita Classic Scale shades from A1 to D4. Manufacturers report that single-color universal composites can be applied to teeth of all colors without using the layering technique using different color composites.
Therefore, the aim of this study is to compare the clinical performance of 2 different single-color universal composite resin materials (OMNICHROMA and Zenchroma) in the restoration of non-carious cervical lesions with the control group (Filtek Z250, 3M), which is a multi-color composite resin material, using modified US Public Health Service (USPHS) and World Dental Federation (FDI) criteria.

Introduction
-----------------
Color selection in the clinic is a very sensitive process and is affected by environmental factors and operator-related variables. This has led to the development of single-color universal composite materials that aim to facilitate color selection. These materials have a universal opacity and several Vita shades and are recommended by manufacturers to be used in a single color layer that can match different tooth colors. As we know, there is no study investigating the clinical performance of these two universal composites. The aim of this study is to compare the clinical performance of 2 different single-color universal composite resin materials (OMNICHROMA and Zenchroma) in the restoration of non-carious cervical lesions with the control group (Filtek Z250, 3M), which is a multi-color composite resin material, using modified USPHS and FDI criteria. In this study, two different null hypotheses were established. The first null hypothesis of this study is; It is concluded that there is no difference between 2 different single color universal composite resin materials (OMNICHROMA and Zenchroma) in terms of clinical performance in restorations of non-carious cervical lesions. The second null hypothesis of the study is that universal composite resin materials are not different from the control group, multicolored composite resin (Filtek Z250, 3M), in terms of clinical performance in restorations of non-carious cervical lesions.

Study Population and Sample Size
-----------------
Non-carious cervical lesions (NCCL) lesions located on first permanent molars and premolars will be selected, according to the FDI criteria. Inclusion criteria for this study are:

-At least 3 teeth with cervical abrasion
-Volunteerily enrolling in the study.

Inclusion of both gender and different teeth types allows the study to detect significant differences related to the materials used for restorations. The study includes 99 male and female patients voluntarily chosen for participation. The data will be collected from six health facilities that operate in Izmir.

Method
-----------------
Patients who have voluntarily agreed to participate in the study will be asked by the clinical coordinator to fill in the consent form. After completing the consent form, patients will be informed about the restoration procedure and postoperative instructions. The color of the teeth will be recorded with the Vita classic scale (N = 16). The selection of 44 teeth for the study will be based on the teeth with the same Vita color (A1-D4).

For each restoration, one tooth will be randomly assigned to OMNICHROMA, one tooth to Zenchroma and the third tooth will be assigned to Filtek Z250. A code will be prepared for all restoration procedures, and each restoration in the same patient will be prepared with one of the 3 materials, which will not be specified to the dentist. The operator who performs clinical and radiographic examinations will be blinded to the restorative materials used in the study. All restorative procedures will be performed by one operator. During this period, a composite color will be prepared as if it is a different tooth to eliminate the operator's habituation to a specific color shade. Each restoration will be restored by a single restoring operator. The operator who prepared the restoration will check the restoration and score the results according to the modified USPHS and FDI criteria (Table 1 and Table 2). The same operator will restore each patient's 3 teeth and apply the same restorative protocol to all teeth.

Tooth preparations for the NCCL will be planned in accordance with the modified USPHS criteria. Full coverage of the preparations will be provided with the use of resin composite. Before restoring each tooth, 35% phosphoric acid (Ultra Etch, 3M) will be applied to the NCCL surface for 15 seconds each time and washed with water. It will be dried gently with a compressed air and cotton roll. After that, Te-Etch ® (Brush & Co) (18% nano-hydroxyapatite primer and 37% phosphoric acid) will be applied for 15 seconds and washed with water. Dentin will be covered with a single layer of nanofilled (Filtek Z250, 3M) and cured in 40 seconds. When the tooth is filled completely, the next step will be filling the cervical margin of the tooth with the universal composite restorative (OMNICHROMA, Zenchroma, Filtek Z250

159.summary:
The goal of this clinical trial is to compare the effect of use of reversal agents for neuromuscular blockade in critically ill patients on time for neurological assessment after endotracheal intubation
The main questions it aims to answer are:
The use of reversal agents for neuromuscular blockade after endotracheal intubation may reduce the time for neurological assessment.
The types of reversal agents for neuromuscular blockade may affect the time for neurological assessment.
Participants will receive different reversal agents or no medications based on the assigned groups. Thirty minutes after intubation using rocuronium, medication is administered, and the time of initial confirmation of eye opening and movement is recorded.
Researchers will compare 3 groups (sugammadex, neostigmine and control(no medication) to see the difference of time for neurological assessment after endotracheal intubation.

160.summary: Up to 60% of endometrial cancer cases are attributed to obesity, in part because obesity promotes development of atypical endometrial hyperplasia (AEH), and up to 40% of women with AEH go on to develop endometrial cancer. The increasing prevalence of obesity in premenopausal women has resulted in increasing rates of AEH in this age group. Hysterectomy with removal of the fallopian tubes and ovaries is 100% effective in preventing endometrial cancer, but this approach results in infertility. Fertility-sparing treatments exist, such as treatment with oral or intrauterine progestin, but these treatments do not work uniformly and do not combat the underlying cause of endometrial cancer, which is obesity and metabolic syndrome. Additionally, up to 41% of women on progestin eventually experience relapse of AEH or endometrial cancer. Third, many patients have insulin resistance that may worsen with progestin therapy. Thus, to improve treatment of AEH and grade 1 endometrial cancer, prevent and reverse endometrial cancer, and allow women to preserve their fertility, the investigators must integrate an effective weight loss strategy to be given with progestin treatment. It is the hypothesis that premenopausal women with endometrial hyperplasia or grade 1 endometrial cancer who desire uterine preservation will be more likely to have atypia-free uterine preservation at two years if they receive progestin in combination with a behavioral weight loss intervention versus progestin plus enhanced usual care.
160.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Overweight and obesity are common among women diagnosed with endometrial lesions, including atypical endometrial hyperplasia (AEH) and grade 1 endometrial cancer. These women, especially those who are premenopausal, wish to preserve their uterine, meaning that they do not wish to undergo hysterectomy for their atypical endometrial hyperplasia or grade 1 endometrial cancer. The primary goal of treatment in these patients is to eliminate the atypia and prevent or delay the development of grade 2 or higher grade endometrial carcinoma or recurrence. Progestin, oral or intrauterine device (IUD), is used as part of standard practice in order to promote atypia elimination. However, the efficacy rate of atypia-free uterine preservation with progestin treatments is only 50%. As such, identifying strategies to increase the effectiveness of progestin treatment in premenopausal women diagnosed with endometrial atypia is important.
This study hypothesizes that weight loss may improve the efficacy of atypia-free uterine preservation with progestin treatment. It is reasonable to assume that, over the course of six months, a modest weight loss of 5% will result in improvements in clinical outcomes. The investigators also believe that the study of a behavioral weight loss intervention may result in the formation of a support network, provide strategies to manage weight, and help women who have received an endometrial diagnosis to develop skills that can help them with weight management in the future.
A two-year randomized prospective study of 50 obese and prematurely menopausal women with AEH or grade 1 endometrial cancer and a uterus will be conducted. Women with endometrial atypia (with complex architecture histologically), grade 1 endometrial cancer, or premenopausal endometrial hyperplasia will undergo a levonorgestrel-releasing IUD insertion and be randomized to receive counseling for an enhanced usual care (EUC) or a novel behavioral weight loss intervention. Randomization will be performed using a computer-generated random numbers table, with a randomization allocation scheme by a statistician who is independent of the randomizing physician. It is expected that over the course of one year, there will be a 19% chance that women assigned to behavioral intervention will achieve atypia-free uterine preservation compared to 12% of women assigned to the EUC. In year 2, those in the EUC will cross over to receive the behavioral weight loss intervention, while the treatment group will receive the standard of care therapy.
Patients will be followed to evaluate uterine preservation and weight status. The investigators will examine the effectiveness of the intervention in reducing the number of participants who will require surgical intervention, including hysterectomy or endometrial resection.
This study will provide information into if a behavioral weight loss intervention can improve the clinical outcomes of women with this diagnosis. It holds the promise of aiding in the prevention of hysterectomy and endometrial resection surgery, which may alleviate the burden of menopause and/or hormonal therapy commonly given after these surgical procedures.
There are no specific conditions on which this study is focused.
160.eval:

161.summary:
The aim of this manuscript is to illustrate a new method permitting safe cholecystectomy in terms of complications with respect to the common bile duct (CBD).
The core of this new technique is identification of the continuity of the cystic duct with the infundibulum. The cystic duct can be identified between the inner gallbladder wall and inflamed outer wall.
In the last 2 years, 3 patients have been treated with the reported technique without complications.
Among the various cholecystectomy procedures, this is a new approach that ensures the safety of the structures of Calot's triangle while providing the advantages gained from total removal of the gallbladder.
161.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Rationale: During many years, cholecystectomy has been considered a safe laparoscopic procedure . However it can turn into a disaster that may require the application of damage control techniques. Many authors have recognized difficulty in performing cholecystectomy following several reports (1)(2)(3)(4)(5). Several methods for performing simple laparoscopic cholecystectomy have been proposed to overcome this difficulty.
Procedure: A new simple technique of subtotal cholecystectomy was recently described (6) to deal with the difficulty associated with cholecystectomy in patients with acute cholecystitis.

Objectives: 
The aim of this paper was to evaluate the safety and feasibility of this technique.
Study Design: 
Fifty patients with acute cholecystitis were enrolled in this study between June of 2005 and June of 2008. All patients had either symptoms or radiological evidence of difficulty and were to be operated on within days of symptom onset. The operative technique was performed as reported by Zhuang et al. The operative procedure was evaluated using the Clavien - Dindo classification. Data was collected using case report forms filled by the investigators. The postoperative course was assessed for 30 days, including the assessment of surgical wound complications, and death.

Results: This procedure seems to offer many advantages compared with other cholecystectomy techniques that have been proposed . It is performed within minutes by a simple operation and represents a feasible and safe technique.

Food and liquid intake postoperatively was allowed on day 1, oral activity and hospital discharge were on day 4. None of the patients died or were converted to an open procedure, and no major morbidity was reported in this series of patients with acute cholecystitis. No leaks were reported nor was there bile duct injury. Three patients were converted into Laparotomic cholecystectomy for reasons not directly related to the technique used in this study (other gallbladder bed attachments). One of the converted patients was a 60 y/o woman who was a type II obesity (BMI 39.2) and was operated on two months after the first presentation with acute cholecystitis. She had a perforated appendix that was treated with necreectomy. She had severe abdominal adhesion and there was an inflammatory induration between the liver and the falciform ligament that prevented performing the operation. This patient underwent a cholecystectomy (performed under General anesthesia) in the same sitting of the laparotomy for appendectomy (there was a 5 cm midline laparotomy incision). Another problem reported with the new technique is an unanticipated bile duct injury which could occur with clipping of the cystic duct. This was not observed in the current study. The remaining 9 patients were laparoscopically operated on without difficulty or complication.
Afterwards, all patients were mobilized in the morning of day 1 and allowed to tolerate food. They were mobilized on day 1 and allowed to tolerate food. Fluids were introduced in the morning of day 1, followed by semisolid diet in the morning of day 2. Oral activity and hospital discharge were both done on day 4.
The mean operative time (from the time of first incision into the stomach until the closure of the last skin incision) was 140 min (95% CI 116 min to 231 min). The mean time required to identify the cystic duct was 14 min (95% CI 10 min to 21 min) and the mean length of hospitalization was 5.4 days (95% CI 4.7 days to 5.9 days). This technique was feasible and safe for use in patients with acute cholecystitis within three days of symptom onset. More studies are needed to confirm our results.

The results of our study indicate that our new technique is safe compared with other traditional techniques. This method seems to be reliable since no biliary duct injuries or leaks were noted in the series.

In summary, the new laparoscopic technique proposed by Zhuang et al. represents a relatively safe and quick operation that seems to be a better approach in patients with acute cholecystitis who are being operated on within 3 days of symptom onset. This technique facilitates a safe

162.summary:
Important psychological problems can be experienced after sports injuries such as anterior cruciate ligament (ACL), these delay physical recovery, affect the quality of rehabilitation and eventually cause problems or re-injuries in the process of returning to sports. The most important of these problems are re-injury anxiety, rehabilitation adherence, rehabilitation self-efficacy problems and kinesiophobia. Although some interventions have been proposed for the solution of these problems, a structured intervention approach has not been put forward yet.
With this research project, our aim is to examine the effectiveness of the Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) protocol (CBT+VR) enriched with the contribution of virtual reality (VR).
The research will be conducted with 60 athletes who meet the inclusion criteria. In the study, which is planned as a 4X5 (groupXmeasurement) mixed factorial design model with four groups (intervention1-intervention2-intervention3, control), the athletes will be filled with psychological assessment scales in order to collect the first data within the first week of starting physical therapy after ACL operation. The data obtained will be analyzed with multi-level statistics. Whether the anxiety levels of the athletes increase in the VR environment will be monitored with the biofeedback system, which will provide concrete data as well as subjective scales.

163.summary:
Despite the need to evolve, the fact that physical therapists are a constrained resource prompts the need for care prioritization that is optimally targeted. It is currently unclear which patients need physical therapist intervention in the hospital, and how much physical therapy is necessary, in order to achieve a functional status that is adequate to discharge home. We have developed a patient-level clinical decision support tool to guide optimal treatment frequency. This tool-the Physical Therapy Frequency Clinical Decision Support Tool, or PT-PENCIL-is based on a statistical model that predicts discharge home relative to the frequency of physical therapist treatment.
The primary goals of this study are to assess the implementation strategy for the PT-PENCIL and analyze its effect on improving the proportion of patients who discharge home.
163.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Introduction and Aims Most patients prefer to discharge from the hospital to their own home, but 11% of all hospitalized patients-and 22.4% of patients with Medicare-require discharge to a post-acute care facility. Hospital systems are increasingly incentivized to facilitate discharge home since a post-acute care facility stay is costly. Post-acute care is most often necessitated by a patient's functional decline during hospitalization. Physical therapists, whose primary treatment objective is generally to improve functional independence, could therefore play a crucial role in promoting improvements in functional status sufficient to enable a greater number of discharges to home. In current practice, however, physical therapists in acute care hospitals do not generally address patients' function-related deficits. They do not generally have the opportunity to do so, since the Inpatient Prospective Payment System incentivizes short hospital stays. Nor have they needed to, since post-acute care facilities have become the primary setting for patients to regain functional independence. In this environment, physical therapists-a constrained resource in most hospitals primarily play a consultative role in which they evaluate functional status during a single visit in order to provide a recommendation for appropriate post-acute rehabilitation needs. With greater focus on ensuring value across the care continuum, healthcare systems are now striving to maintain short hospital stays, but also limit post-acute care utilization. This will require patients to achieve greater functional independence as quickly as possible within their hospital stay. Thus, the role of physical therapists in acute care hospitals must evolve. Intervention Despite the need to evolve, the fact that physical therapists are a constrained resource prompts the need for care prioritization that is optimally targeted. It is currently unclear which patients need physical therapist intervention in the hospital, and how much physical therapy is necessary, in order to achieve a functional status that is adequate to discharge home. We have developed a patient-level clinical decision support tool to guide optimal treatment frequency. This tool-the Physical Therapy Frequency Clinical Decision Support Tool, or PT-PENCIL-is based on a statistical model that predicts discharge home relative to the frequency of physical therapist treatment. The primary goals of this study are to assess the development and implementation strategy for the PT-PENCIL and analyze its effect on improving the proportion of patients who discharge home. The PT-PENCIL will include two solutions integrated into the electronic health record (Epic). For both, Epic will use the underlying statistical model to identify patients for whom daily physical therapy may be indicated in order to facilitate a discharge to home. For such patients, an Epic best practice advisory (BPA) alert will appear on the screen, which will prompt therapists to consider a visit on the next day. The second Epic-integrated solution is an indicator column on the patient lists maintained by therapists, which will identify patients who would benefit from daily PT (a green dot), those who would not (a red dot), and those for whom the PT-PENCIL did not run in Epic. PT-PENCIL will be implemented into clinical care by means of a pilot hybrid type 2 design, informed by the PRISM (Practical, Robust Implementation and Sustainability Model) and RE-AIM (reach, effectiveness, adoption, implementation, and maintenance) frameworks. We will accomplish the following primary specific aims: Aim 1: Analyze the effect of using the PT-PENCIL on the proportion of patients discharged home. Aim 2: Assess the reach, adoption, acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of the PT-PENCIL.

Official Title
-----------------
Analysis of a Stepped-Wedge Implementation of the PT-PENCIL Tool

Conditions

Physical Therapy Evaluation

Intervention / Treatment

Participation Criteria

Eligibility Criteria

Inclusion Criteria: Admitted for at least one overnight Total ICU LOS < 48 hours Primary medical service is any of: cardiology, vascular medicine, cardiac surgery, thoracic surgery, vascular surgery, dermatology, endocrinology, hepatology, internal medicine, obstetrics/gynecology, pulmonology, nephrology, urology, colorectal surgery, general surgery, neurology, neurosurgery Exclusion - Individuals under the age of 18.

Ages Eligible for Study
-----------------
Minimum Age: 18 Years

Sexes Eligible for Study

166.summary: This research study aims to bridge the gap in the existing literature by comparing the efficacy of Maitland mobilization and PFS techniques in the treatment of post-traumatic stiff elbow. While existing research has shown the favorable effects of joint mobilization and muscle energy techniques in other musculoskeletal conditions, there is a notable gap in understanding their efficacy in post-traumatic stiff elbow, particularly in Pakistan where no such study has been conducted. By investigating the comparative outcomes of these techniques, this research will contribute valuable clinical insights, potentially guiding clinicians in selecting the most effective treatment approach and laying the foundation for evidence-based treatment protocols tailored to patients with post-traumatic stiff elbow.
166.model_output:
<|assistant|>
The elbow is a hinge joint; it has the highest risk of degeneration. Range of motion (ROM) deficit could result in both a functional and cosmetic deficit. Stiff elbow can be due to capsular contracture, which is a result of scar tissue formation around the elbow joint. Stiff elbow can be also cause by post-traumatic joint effusion, elbow fracture, dislocation and POP. The aim of this study was to compare, Maitland Mobilization and Post Facilitation stretch in improving ROM in the post- traumatic stiff elbow patients. Maitland mobilization and PFS are common interventions applied in managing stiff elbow. Studies have revealed that PFS is more effective than Maitland mobilization in managing stiff elbow. As there is no definitive study comparing post facilitation stretch and maitland mobilization in post-traumatic elbow contracture, that was the rationale of designing this study. This study was prospective; randomized; controlled clinical trial. Forty-three participants were enrolled in the study. Outcome measures were ROM at the elbow, forearm supination and pronation. Numeric Pain Rating Scale and DASH scoring was also observed. The study found that significant improvement in all outcome measures were seen in both treatment groups. PFS group showed statistically significant improvement in ROM ELbow flexion and extension, and forearm ROM when compared to pretreatment assessment, whereas statistically significant and clinically meaningful improvements were seen in Paitland elbow mobilization group, in ROM Elbow Flexion and Extension and forearm ROM in between the two groups.

The study used the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) score and the Analgesia Nociception Index (ANI) for dynamic pain assessment, 24-hour morphine consumption for static pain assessment, and adverse reactions for side-effect assessment. The results showed that the 2 ultrasound-guided analgesia methods (TLIP block and ESP block) can effectively reduce the stress reaction caused by the patient's autonomic nervous system during surgery, maintain the stability of the patient's vital signs during and after surgery, and improve the overall postoperative quality of patients by 1 score improvement in VAS score. TLIP block is more effective than ESP block in terms of postoperative pain relief and requires less morphine dosage. Overall, TLIP block is a better perioperative analgesic than ESP block for patients with lumbar spine fusion surgery.

Purpose: Investigate the safe wearability and basic functionality - epidermal melanin concentration and blood oxygen estimation - of our developed device: Melanin-Adjusted Blood Oxygen Sensor (MABOS)
Participants: Healthy adults 18-65 years of age
Procedures (methods): The investigators plan to enroll 12 healthy adult participants for the study. The investigators aim to enroll 4 participants with skin tones associated with those of African descent (Group A), 4 of East Asian descent (Group B), and 4 of European descent (Group C). Additionally, the investigators aim to ensure half of group is male, and the other half female. For the duration of the study, two wearable devices will be placed on the participant: a Nonin PureSat pulse oximeter on a forefinger, and the novel wearable pulse oximeter - MABOS - on the other forefinger. Prior to testing, an Ocean HR2 XR Spectrometer will be used to assess the absorbance of three wavelengths of light - 410, 660, 940 nm - on each patient's inner wrist. Following this, the two devices will be placed on the patient, set up, and calibrated for 10 minutes. During the calibration period, MABOS will be used to measure the same three wavelengths of light utilized by the Ocean HR2 XR Spectrometer (410, 660, and 940 nm). After the calibration period, all participants will be asked to perform the following procedure 5 times as part of the testing period: a deep inhalation lasting no longer than 10 seconds, followed by a slow exhalation lasting no longer than 30 seconds. Between each trial, a five-minute break will be required. For the entire testing period, all two devices will be continuously acquiring data. After this testing period, all two devices will continue taking measurements until 90 minutes have elapsed. Skin integrity will be examined before spectrometer use, after spectrometer use, after the calibration period, every 30 minutes after the start of the testing period, and after the testing period. During the study, if the participants report any uncomfortable feeling and/or pain or if a change to the skin at the site of device placement occurs, the measurements will be discontinued, and all the devices placed on the participants will be removed. Questionnaires will be provided after the study period and during follow-up visits approximately 48 hours and 96 hours post the device testing visit for a proof-of-concept evaluation of the safe wearability.

175.summary:
Sleep of critically ill patients is highly disturbed with a high sleep fragmentation; patients spend most of their sleep in very short sleep episodes, lasting less than 10 minutes. Causes of theses sleep alterations are complex including environmental noise (alarms, beepers, conversations…), continuous light, nurse care and repetitive measures of vital parameters.
Numerous studies have reported a relationship between severe sleep alterations and a prolonged weaning period and mortality. Improving sleep quality in critically ill patients is a major challenge to promote ICU patient's recovery.
A very promising treatment is the application of a nocturnal  quiet-time  during which non urgent care, comfort care, systematic measures of vital parameters are delayed and clustered in order to limit room entries. However,  quiet time  procedures have failed to improve sleep quality to date.
A miniaturized medical device recording one EEG channel and embedding an automated sleep scoring algorithm running in real-time was devised. This device (positioned on forehead, and continuously recording noise and light levels) indicates if the patient is awake or asleep using a tablet positioned at doorstep of the room, so that nurses know if patient is sleeping, without entering the room.
Hypothesis proposes that applying sleep protection procedures (clustering cares, limiting room entries, reducing lights and noise, delaying non urgent care…) when patients are sleeping (= EEG-guided strategies) will increase patients sleep quality.
This study will assess the effect of such device on sleep quality in ICU patients. This is a before / after design. The first group (control group), will be recorded but the sleep scoring will not be displayed by the tablet and patient will be expose to standard care. Then, procedure will be established collegially with nurses, nurses assistants and doctors. Then, the second group (treated group) will be recorded with the device displaying the status of the patient (asleep/awake) and all caregivers will be asked to follow the established rules (EEG-guided sleep protection rules)
175.model_output:
<|assistant|>
It is well-known that an altered sleep is often found in ICU and critically ill patients. Sleep quality and duration have been previously reported to be disturbed in critically ill patients. Critical care setting is characterized by multiple light variations due to frequent opening of doors with entrance of medical and paramedical staff, interruption by medical devices and alarms. Indeed, in this environment, sleep quality is reported to be disturbed due to interruptions by staff, alarms and light variations. Although hospitalized patients are recommended to sleep 8 hours a day in a room free of light, noise and disturbances, this is particularly difficult to achieve in intensive care.
To the best of our knowledge, there are currently no data on the sleep quality of in-hospital intensive care unit patients. Furthermore, there is no systematic practice to optimize sleep (particularly at night) quality in critically ill patients. These lack of data on sleep quality, absence of specific care dedicated to sleep and the current trend to deliver care closer to the patient's room, prompt us to propose a novel approach, that is the use of an electroencephalogram (EEG) guided sleep protection method. Indeed, by monitoring continuously the EEG traces, we can distinguish between sleep and wake phases. When sleep is detected, the system displays an alert which advises the caregivers to protect the patient from care interruption or noise. Although the study has not been reported, this approach is currently used by several health care institutions in Europe.
The objective is to evaluate the impact of EEG-guided protection of the patients' sleep in intensive care and its effect on patients' sleep quality, sleep fragmentation, environmental noise and light exposure, caregiver and patients agitation. In addition, we will quantify the impact of sleep optimization on patient, caregiver and society benefits as indicated on the health-economic analysis by the French high authority of health (Haute Autorité de Santé) which is a key priority for ICU work. Furthermore, the feasibility of such a method and its effect on patient safety (respiratory failure) and workload of staff members involved in the care of the patients will be assessed.

178.summary:
The goal of this randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study is to assess whether the food supplement Endocalyx Pro reduces sodium and water excess in patients with chronic heart failure.
The main questions it aims to answer are:
To assess whether the food supplement Endocalyx reduces sodium and water excess in patients with chronic heart failure.
To determine the contribution of different potential working mechanisms of Endocalyx in heart failure patients.
To evaluate whether the food supplement Endocalyx will improve patient-reported outcomes such as fluid overload symptoms and quality of life.
To confirm the previously demonstrated safety of Endocalyx in subjects with chronic heart failure.
Participants will be randomized to Endocalyx Pro or Placebo daily for 8 weeks, and will be followed 12 weeks.
178.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Detailed Description
-----------------
Nearly 30 million people worldwide suffer from chronic heart failure (HF), a condition for which effective long-term treatment options are greatly needed. While the pathogenesis of HF is multifactorial, one of the key underlying mechanisms is the disruption of the endocalyx, a glycocalyx layer that lines the blood vessels and regulates the exchange of water and electrolytes between blood and the cardiovascular system. This mechanism occurs even in patients with HF who have otherwise normal kidney function. The key consequence is fluid excess which results in symptoms like peripheral edema and shortness of breath. This fluid excess is typically managed by diuretic treatment, but excessive use of diuretics often leads to electrolyte depletion and worsening of kidney function. Therefore, a non-diuretic treatment option that will allow patients to be less dependent on diuretics is urgently needed. However, existing non-diuretic treatment options are either not effective or are associated with negative consequences. Thus there is a clear clinical need for finding treatments that will help HF patients deal with the fluid excess without relying on diuretics. The main goal of the current investigation is to determine the efficacy of the food supplement Endocalyx in dealing with the fluid excess of chronic HF. For patients with long-term chronic HF, fluid excess can manifest in a variety of ways. Most patients experience symptoms such as shortness of breath and peripheral edema, while others develop hypertension or may have a worsening of kidney function. Endocalyx is a food supplement that has shown to reduce sodium storage in the small intestine, and as a result increase sodium excretion in healthy volunteers. However, the effect of Endocalyx on patients with long-term chronic HF remains unknown. In the current study we will test whether Endocalyx can decrease sodium and water excess in patients with chronic HF. In an explorative pilot study we have previously demonstrated that Endocalyx also has positive effects on blood pressure control and microcirculation in patients with chronic HF and diabetes mellitus with hypertension. This study was not powered to directly demonstrate these effects. For the current study we will perform a randomized, placebo-controlled trial focused on patients with heart failure and fluid excess, as manifested by elevated NT-proBNP levels or symptoms such as shortness of breath, peripheral edema, hypertension or worsening kidney function. The primary outcome will be the degree of fluid excess or symptom burden based on the change in NT-proBNP levels. Secondary outcomes will include changes in body weight, blood pressure, hemodynamic parameters, total body water and urinary sodium excretion as well as adverse events. We aim to include 50 patients. As many as 1 out of 3 patients will drop out prematurely leading to an estimation of an n = 74, which will give a 80% power to identify a 30% difference in NT-proBNP levels between the two study arms, assuming a significance level of 5%. Sample size calculations were performed using the program G*Power, version 3.1.9.

Small bowel obstruction (SBO) is one of the most common causes of serious gastrointestinal disease in the US. Adhesion-related SBO (aSBO) is usually treated by the placement of a nasogastric tube (NGT) to decompress the stomach, administration of intravenous (IV) fluids and observation by a surgical team.
The purpose of this feasibility study is to determine the potential for implementation of treatment protocols for aSBO and determine the feasibility of randomizing patients with aSBO to receive or not receive NGTs or water-soluble contrast (WSC). The investigators will also determine the ability to measure HRQOL as a main outcome for the treatment of aSBO. The studies outlined in this research program intend to address gaps in knowledge about how to determine who benefits from NGT placement, who can be managed without them, how to objectively determine when a bowel obstruction has resolved, how to reintroduce feeding to patients with aSBO, what criteria should be used for hospital discharge and what role cathartics such as WSC contrast have in the management of aSBO.
This feasibility study will enroll a limited number of patients (n=40) who will be followed for up to 30 days.
