180.summary: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection is a major public health threat in China. At present, a functional cure, also known as clinical cure or sustained Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) loss, is recommended as the ideal endpoint of HBV treatment. However, HBsAg loss can be achieved in less than 10% of chronic hepatitis B (CHB) patients treated with current available antiviral drug interferon (IFNα) or nucleos(t)ide analogues (NAs) monotherapy. With the support of the national major special funding for infectious diseases from 11th Five-Year Plan to 13th Five-Year Plan, we have implemented a pioneer clinical study of sequential combination of IFNα therapy on NAs to treat NAs-treated CHB patients (ie. New Switch Study). This is the world's first clinical trial aiming to functional cure, which increased the rate of HBsAg loss to 15% in the overall population in our study, and to 30-50% among those with lower baseline HBsAg levels. How to further improve the HBsAg loss rate is an urgent issue for us. The key point of achieving functional cure is to reverse the HBV-specific T cell exhaustion and establish the long-term immune control against HBV infection. (Programmed death-1) PD-1/programmed death-ligand 1 (PD-L1) axis blockade has been demonstrated to reinvigorate exhausted CD8+ T cells, and would be a potential strategy to treat chronic HBV infection. In this study, a large multicenter prospective study will be performed to explore the safety and efficacy of a novel combination strategy involving immune checkpoint inhibitor (anti-PD-1 antibody) and IFNα in CHB patients, observe the HBsAg loss rate in NA-treated CHB patients receiving this combination strategy, evaluate the potential of breaking immune tolerance by this strategy, and further assess its efficacy to further improve the clinical cure rate on the basis of New Switch Study. Based on New Switch Study, this study further attempts to reverse T cell exhaustion in CHB patients, explore a novel platform of combination therapy development for clinical cure, and ultimately increase the HBsAg loss rate to higher than 50% in overall patients. The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the burden of HBV infection in China and contribute to the goal of global elimination of hepatitis B and C by 2030 (WHO 2030).
180.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Chemotherapy combined with immunotherapy has the synergistic effect on tumors, and has emerged as a new breakthrough in tumor treatment. HBsAg loss is an ideal treatment outcome. Studies have shown that tumor immune surveillance has immune dysfunction, which is reflected in defective dendritic cells and dysfunctional T cells. Therefore, activating innate immune system (dendritic cell, NK cells and antiviral CD8+T cells) and adaptive immune system (lymphocyte subsets) play important roles in the anti-tumor effect. This research plan is designed using a triple combined therapy approach (immunotherapy) to aim at the functional cure for chronic Hepatitis B. We select anti-PD-1 antibody, NAs and peginterferon alfa-2a (peg-IFNα) for the treatment of hepatitis B virus (HBV), so as to activate the host's innate and adaptive immune systems, eliminate HBV-infected cells, and maintain a persistently high level of HBsAg-specific T cells that can control HBV replication to reduce the incidence of HBV DNA reappearance. This design of the clinical treatment approach is expected to achieve effective control of HBV replication, maintain HBeAg negative state, and achieve the goal of sustained HBsAg loss, thereby realizing the functional cure of hepatitis B virus.

181.summary:
The study is aimed to compare two different suture techniques in terms of wound healing. In this research, which is designed as an observational study, a comparison of simple and locked continuous suture techniques will be done. For this purpose, Selçuk University Faculty of Dentistry, Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, being treated at the full arch flap opened (for alveoplasty). Half of the arch will be closed by simple suture, the other half will be closed by continuous suture technique.
It is planned to evaluate wound healing with the Landry Healing Index and Early Wound Healing Score. It is planned to measure the amount of knot looseness in millimeters on the 7th day when the sutures will be removed. On the 7th day, it is planned to evaluate the suture removal pain for the patient and the ease of suture removal for the operator with the VAS scale. Data collected from these assessments will be statistically compared for simple and continuous sutures.

<|assistant|>
The purposes of this study aim to detect suture wound loosening in mouth and its related symptoms under experimental conditions with different suture techniques.
Mouth wound loosening is one of the main complications related to periodontal surgery, and it can negatively affect the periodontal therapy. After a full arch alveoplasty, the surgical wound should be closed and sutured at the end of the operation. However, a well-known clinical concern is loosening of the suture material. Since loosening of sutures is related with increased morbidity and discomfort for patients, it is important to investigate suture loosening and its related symptoms.
In several clinical studies, it has been reported that different suture techniques result in different rates of suture loosening. However, due to the lack of similarity and comparison among studies, clear evidence of the influence of different suture techniques on suture loosening has not been found so far. It is known that the time required to knot or suture is longer for the full arch alveoplasty operation. According to the clinical experience in the division of oral surgery in Istanbul Medipol University, the suture wound loosening is more difficult after full arch suturing without interruption.
In this study, the investigators planned to detect early wound healing parameters and suture loosening according to suture techniques between full arch alveoplasty. The null hypothesis for this study is that continuous suture methods should not be different from simple wound closure methods, in terms of suture loosening parameters, and any suturing techniques should not show significant difference in terms of suture loosening parameters. For this purpose, one hundred and eight patients who were candidates for the same full arch alveoplasty treatment in Istanbul Medipol University Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery are included in this study. Patients, aged between 40 and 65, who were candidates for the same full arch alveoplasty are treated under similar conditions.
To detect whether early wound healing score, laundry healing index, suturing time, suture removal difficulty, pain, suture loosening are related to suturing techniques in Istanbul Medipol University, the null hypothesis about there is nothing different about continuous suture methods compared to simple wound closure methods in terms of suture loosening parameters in the full arch suturing in oral surgery is analyzed. If the null hypothesis is proven wrong, the investigators should conclude that the simple suture technique gives less wound loosening related morbidity.

183.summary:
DMEK (Descemet Membrane Endothelial Keratoplasty) is a surgical technique used to treat primary or secondary corneal endothelial decompensation. At the Rothschild Foundation, as in many Western referral centers, DMEK is currently the surgical technique of choice for the treatment of primary or secondary corneal endothelial decompensation.
Technically challenging, it is a relatively tedious surgery to learn, but offers the best visual and refractive results, as well as faster visual and functional recovery in simple cases.
In patients without anterior or posterior segment surgical history, the complication rate of DMEK, including graft rejection, is similar to that of other endothelial keratoplasty surgical techniques.
However, in specific cases, in patients with a history of ophthalmological surgery such as vitrectomy, trabeculectomy, large iris defects, anterior synechiae, aniridia or aphakia, the scientific literature shows a higher complication rate for DMEK (increased rate of rebulling and graft decompensation).
As a result, other techniques that are less effective on visual results continue to be used for these patients in a large number of centers.
Nonetheless, in our department, DMEK is also performed on these complicated patients.
When it comes to patients with a history of anterior or posterior segment surgery, it seems to us that the surgeons' experience with DMEK allows better visual results than with any other technique, but without any back up regarding the complication rate in the literature.
The main aim of this study is to describe, in patients with a history of anterior or posterior segment surgery undergoing DMEK, the 12-months occurrence rate of at least one serious post-operative complication.
183.model_output:
<|assistant|>
During the last two decades, corneal endothelial replacement (DMEK) has become an established surgical technique for the treatment of cases of Fuchs' endothelial dystrophy. The use of DMEK in the presence of pre-existing retinal surgery, and especially in its absence, remains subject to discussion among corneal surgeons, with opinions ranging from "the treatment is contraindicated" (in the absence of retinal surgery) to "the treatment is not contraindicated and is even recommended" (in the absence of retinal surgery).
The hypothesis of the present study is that DMEK performed in patients with retinal surgery or with a history of anterior segment surgery (cataract, IOL implantation, filtering bleb) presents a serious risk of surgical complication. The investigators hypothesize the opposite in the case of patients with a history of pars plana vitrectomy and / or with an implanted intraocular lens.
This prospective monocentric randomized study will compare the occurrence rate of serious post-operative complications of DMEK in the three groups of patients mentioned above, as well as the improvement in visual acuity from both unaided and corrected eyes one year after surgery.
The main objective is to quantify the occurrence rate of post-operative complications, namely the composite endpoints consisting of corneal detachment requiring graft redressing under air or gas, corneal edema requiring reoperation, corneal stromal graft rejection requiring reoperation, and the development of cystoid macular edema.
The secondary objectives concern the evolution of visual and refractive results of the operated eye, the endothelial density and morphometry of the corneal graft one year after surgery, the evolution of intraocular pressure, the complication rate of phacoemulsification or DMEK combined after one year of surgery, and the analysis of the surgical time.
The analysis of these results will confirm the need for a DMEK surgery in specific patient groups or the need to avoid surgery in others. This analysis will also provide additional data for surgeons wishing to perform DMEK surgery in non-uniform groups, and contribute to defining better indications for DMEK surgery in patients with a history of anterior segment procedure.

184.summary:
The microbiome, the collection of microorganisms that live in our gut, plays an important role in maintaining our health, proper nutrient absorption, nutrient turnover and immunity. After birth, a symbiotic relationship develops with the strains of bacteria that colonise our gut, and the presence and proportion of bacteria is individualised and highly variable.
A healthy bacterial flora is essential for the cells of the intestinal mucosa. Glycoproteins in the cell surface mucus coat are important nutrients for bacteria, while some bacterial strains supply mucosal cells with nutrient molecules (e.g. short-chain fatty acids) that are their essential energy source.
An abnormal change in the proportion of bacterial strains that make up the microbiome, dysbacteriosis, in which pathogenic bacteria proliferate at the expense of members of the normal flora, can cause a number of pathologies. Nutrient supply to the cells of the mucosa is reduced, making them more vulnerable and leading to various pathological conditions.
The microbiome and the essential nutrients they produce have also been found to play an important role in wound healing. A decrease in the diversity of the microbiome, an increase in the relative number of pathogenic bacteria and a decrease in the proportion of 'beneficial' bacteria increases the risk of surgical complications of infection and suture failure.

AL is detected in intraoperative specimen, the AL-group is examined postoperatively by colonoscopy or abdominal CT scan. Differences in microbial composition between the anastomoses of patients suffering from AL and those without AL are analysed by high throughput sequencing of bacteria and viruses. Furthermore a possible correlation of the microbiome with septic complications is examined.

187.summary:
Normal embryonic development relies on the correct transmission of genetic information, and sperm DNA plays a crucial part in this process. Causes of poor sperm DNA integrity include unhealthy lifestyles such as smoking and exposure to gonadotoxins, as well as, obesity, varicoceles, infections, advanced paternal age and systemic disorders. An increase in DNA fragmentation in sperm has been linked to lower fertilisation rate, poorer quality embryos, lower pregnancy rate, and high miscarriages rate.
The best way for sperm selection and processing in assisted reproductive technologies (ART) should be noninvasive and cost-effective. It should also make it possible to identify high-quality spermatozoa and produce more favorable results in terms of pregnancy and live birth rates.7 Meanwhile, the microfluidic sperm separation technology is a less expensive and less invasive alternative. This method allows for the selection of motile sperm that have a normal morphology, low levels of reactive oxygen species (ROS), and low DFI

188.summary: The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of stabilization and stabilization-related parameters on shooting performance at the cervical, lumbal and scapular levels in archery athletes. A total of 40 archery athletes aged between 10 and 18, who have been professionally engaged in archery for at least 1 year were included in the study. Demographic information and musculoskeletal system evaluations of the athletes were done. Performance of the athletes via Upper Extremity Closed Kinetic Chain Stability Test, Hand Grip Strength test; presence of scapular dyskinesia was evaluated via the Lateral Scapular Slide Test. Cervical region stabilization was evaluated via Craniocervical Flexion Test, scapular level stabilization was evaluated via Scapular Muscle Endurance Test, lumbar region stabilization was evaluated via Abdominal Drawing-in Test and Sahrmann's Core Stability Test. As the parameters related to stabilization, postures via Corbin Postural Rating Scale; balances via Stork Balance Test, Upper Extremity Y Balance Test; pain was evaluated via the Shoulder Pain and Disability Index. Shooting performances were evaluated with 72 target shootings and a total of 720 points. .

The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of stabilization and stabilization-related parameters on shooting performance at the cervical, lumbal and scapular levels in archery athletes. 40 archery athletes aged between 10 and 18, who have been professionally engaged in archery for at least 1 year were included in the study. Demographic information and musculoskeletal system evaluations of the athletes were done. Performance of the athletes via Upper Extremity Closed Kinetic Chain Stability Test, Hand Grip Strength test; presence of scapular dyskinesia was evaluated via the Lateral Scapular Slide Test. Cervical region stabilization was evaluated via Craniocervical Flexion Test, scapular level stabilization was evaluated via Scapular Muscle Endurance Test, lumbar region stabilization was evaluated via Abdominal Drawing-in Test and Sahrmann's Core Stability Test. As the parameters related to stabilization, postures via Corbin Postural Rating Scale; balances via Stork Balance Test, Upper Extremity Y Balance Test; pain was evaluated via the Shoulder Pain and Disability Index. Shooting performances were evaluated with 72 target shootings and a total of 720 points.  There was no significant difference between two groups in terms of total shooting performance (p = 0.13). The two athletes belonging to the upper extremity performance group were scored higher in each session than the other athlete in terms of upper extremity performance with only one clicker test. There were no significant differences between two groups in terms of scapular dyskinesia (p = 0.057). There are significant relationships between upper extremity performance, shooting performance and scapular dyskinesia (r = 0.495, r = 0.448 and r = -0.474) and there is significant relationships between upper extremity closed chain stability test and the presence of scapular dyskinesia (r = 0.403). The study results showed that there was a positive relationship between the muscle strength performance, scapula muscle endurance performance and upper extremity performance. However, there was no difference between the groups in terms of total shooting performance. Our study showed that all stabilization-related parameters measured; muscle strength, muscle endurance, postural stability are related to upper extremity performance and scapular dyskinesia in archery athletes. However; further studies with larger series are needed to clarify the relationship between stabilization performance and the shooting performance of archery athletes.

189.summary: In order to support the desire of most adolescents to delay pregnancy (parenting) until their own adulthood, pediatricians must be comfortable and skilled in having reproductive health conversations with adolescents and the mothers of adolescents. Artificial intelligence, such as a chatbot, could be programmed to simulate the perspective of the mother or the daughter as a tool for pediatricians to practice communication before interacting with real families. Through human-centered design, an iterative problem-solving approach, our overall goal is to develop and test a communication training chatbot tool that is accurate, developmentally tailored for adolescents and mothers, culturally tailored, and aids pediatricians to manage resistance and conflict about contraception to ultimately close disparities in teen births. The investigator's primary hypothesis is that a communication focused intervention will improve pediatrician interactions with dyads about contraception. Through three stages, the study team will develop an artificial intelligence tool as a behavioral intervention. The study team will gather basic communication data to generate, refine, modify, adapt, and pilot test novel communication tools with real-world encounters while keeping humans at the center of attention
189.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Background: Sexual and reproductive health concerns often arise, but adolescents may be reluctant to discuss these sensitive topics with their parent or provider. Despite clear benefits to contraception use, adolescents may experience challenges in the quality of communication discussing contraception with their providers that can influence their sexual health outcomes. Mothers and daughters are increasingly accessing primary care. Providers may feel unprepared in discussions around contraception. Although a variety of communication training programs exist for pediatrician trainees and health providers, none are culturally appropriate, family based or designed to address the challenges of adolescent reproductive health. Objectives: To characterize the quality of sexual and reproductive health encounters involving adolescents, mothers and their provider in pediatric primary care settings. To evaluate a conversation skills intervention for providers and assess its impact on communication quality of sexual and reproductive health encounters. To identify communication strategies preferred by adolescents and their family that may be embedded in a chatbot communication training program. Methods: This study will be conducted in three stages. In Stage 1 (formative) (50 encounters), we will characterize the quality of sexual and reproductive health encounters involving adolescents, mothers and their provider in pediatric primary care settings. Through separate post-encounter surveys of each triad member, we will determine ideal, moderate, and poor communication interactions with a 4-point Likert scale to describe the overall quality of the interactions (concordant contraception plans, satisfaction), communication (confidence, comfort, self-efficacy, confidentiality) and decision-making (perceived autonomy, ownership and power) to determine ideal, moderate, and poor communication interactions. In Stage 2 (development), we will use machine learning algorithms to design virtual conversations for providers, adolescents and mothers. In Stage 3 (proof-of-concept), we will test how an AI communication training intervention tool can influence triadic interactions by comparing evaluation results of 50 pre and 50 post training encounters using the same assessments as in Stage 1. The investigators will enroll ten physician learners who will train with the chatbot communication training program as a behavioral intervention. Before the training, the 10 learners will complete 5 sexual health clinical encounters with adolescent-mother dyads (50 total encounters) that will be audio-recorded and post-encounter surveys completed. After training with the tool, the same 10 learners will complete 5 more clinical encounters with adolescent-mother dyads (50 total encounters) in the same format to assess for improvement in communication interactions. Discussion: This study aims to provide innovative approaches to train pediatricians in adolescent sexual health care. This project addresses a critical gap in evidence-based communication training interventions for pediatricians focusing on underserved adolescents. Expected outcome of this project will be a culturally appropriate and family-focused conversation skills training for pediatricians engaging with adolescents and parents.
189.eval:
Goal Alignment: 1

190.summary:
Vitiligo is an acquired, non contagious skin disorder characterised by depigmented patches of skin that may appear in a localised or very generalised distribution, and affecting 0.5-2.0% of the global population.There are however, limited population-based studies on the burden of vitiligo and disparities across people of different ethnicities and deprivation.
The overall purpose of this study is to provide an estimate of the lifetime risk of vitiligo in the population overall and by sociodemographic subgroups. Moreover, to do a subgroup analysis in the vitiligo population to identify health-related disparities across people in different sex, age, deprivation and ethnicity. A detailed understanding of the burden of disease in different sociodemographic groups is vital to plan resource provision.
190.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Background: There is little information about vitiligo which characterises healthcare disparities in vitiligo, despite mounting evidence about the psychological impact of vitiligo. The aim of this study is to assess and characterise mental health and related issues in a vitiligo cohort recruited from a large electronic healthcare database. Healthcare disparities: Mental health conditions; healthcare utilisation including primary care encounters, dermatology referrals and mental health referrals; and work impact (time off work and unemployment) will be assessed for people with vitiligo compared to those without vitiligo.
Design: This will be a retrospective observational cohort study. A large electronic healthcare database, the Optimum Patient Care Record (OPCRD), will be interrogated prospectively to identify people with vitiligo and those without vitiligo, from 2004 to 2020. The endpoints for both cohorts will be examined during the following two years (2020-2021). Patients with vitiligo, compared with those without, will be described demographically and followed up with data on mental health referrals, primary care referrals, time off work, and unemployment. The cumulative lifetime incidence and prevalence of vitiligo will be estimated at age 80 years using survival models and plotted by age, gender, socioeconomic profile and ethnicity.
Outcomes: Primary outcomes will include the frequency of mental health referrals, primary care encounters, time off work and unemployment in people with vitiligo compared with those without disease. Secondary outcomes will include prevalence rates of mental health conditions and time to first mental health referral event in the vitiligo population. The cumulative lifetime risk of vitiligo will be estimated by baseline characteristics age, gender, sex, ethnicity and deprivation.
Study size: The cumulative lifetime risk based on 16 years of follow up, accounting for competing risk of death would identify vitiligo in approximately >350,000 individuals.
Investigative team: A multidisciplinary research team of clinicians, epidemiologists, statisticians, a patient group representative and a patient representative will work closely throughout this project.

192.summary: This phase I/Ib trial tests the safety, side effects, and best dose of vinorelbine when given in combination with trotabresib in treating patients with HER2 positive breast cancer that has spread to the central nervous system or leptomeninges (metastasis). Cancer cells that make too much HER2 may grow more quickly and are more likely to spread to other parts of the body as metastases, including the central nervous system. Trotabresib is part of a family of drugs called BET inhibitors. Trotabresib may stop the growth of tumor cells by blocking some of the enzymes needed for cell growth. Vinorelbine is in a class of medications called vinca alkaloids. It works by slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells in your body. Giving trotabresib and vinorelbine may increase in the anti-cancer activity of vinorelbine when used in combination with radiation (radiotherapy).
192.model_output:
<|assistant|>
The NCCN guidelines for the management of brain metastases recommend localized therapy, including surgery and stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS), in patients with good performance status, no leptomeningeal disease, and controlled extracranial disease. The investigators believe that it is reasonable to include such patients in a study of vinorelbine and trotabresib. Trotabresib is thought to inhibit poly-ADP-ribose-polymerase (PARP), which is commonly altered in HER2-enriched cancers and is also known to function in DNA repair inhibition, and to be particularly effective as a therapeutic agent in breast tumors harboring loss of function mutations that are thought to lead to deficient homologous recombination DNA repair, even in the absence of overt mutations, loss of function or reduced expression in the PARP pathway. There is some evidence that Vinorelbine might enhance the effectiveness of cytotoxic radiotherapy in CNS. This study will investigate the safety and effectiveness of 3-week cycles of vinorelbine (9 mg/m2 intravenous over 10 minutes) along with trotabresib administered orally during the entire week (25 mg/day) immediately after the completion of radiation therapy to brain metastases or leptomeningeal disease. The investigators aim to determine the highest tolerated dose of this combination. The investigators believe that this treatment regimen with radiotherapy, followed by vinorelbine and trotabresib, will provide an effective and well-tolerated therapeutic approach for patients with limited metastatic disease to the central nervous system.

193.summary: More than 30% of Black women with obesity binge eat. Binge eating may increase the risk for the development of metabolic syndrome and binge-eating-disorder (BED), which is associated with severe obesity. Though several effective treatments for binge eating exist, Black women have not fared well. Not only has their inclusion in treatment trials been limited, but when participating, they are more likely to drop out, and/or lose less weight, compared to their White counterparts. Furthermore, treatment for binge eating is often not available in primary care and community-based settings places where Black women are more likely to receive treatment for their eating and weight-related concerns. Currently, there is scant intervention research to treat binge eating in Black women. With the highest rates of obesity (57%) nationally, Black women are in need of culturally-relevant treatments for binge eating and weight gain prevention. Given the established relationship between frequent binge eating and subsequent weight gain, addressing binge eating among Black women with obesity is imperative.
193.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Our primary goal is to develop a culturally-relevant digital health tool for Black women to detect and treat binge eating in Black women with obesity. Our secondary goal is to demonstrate the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of the digital health program to prevent weight re-gain. A priori sample size calculations indicate we can detect feasibility and preliminary efficacy for the program (based on previous findings). We will use a randomized clinical trial design with 40 participants. This protocol will be the first to focus on preventing weight gain and reducing binge eating among Black women with obesity by implementing a culturally-relevant digital health tool. The program will utilize an approach of "centering" body signals, a cognitive behavioral strategy to better understand and respond to internal eating cues of hunger and satiety. The program's content and design will be informed by a formative process with Black obese women and their primary care providers (PCPs) to optimize engagement and retention in a 6-month study. Intervention Phase: The study will be in two phases: 12-week Feasibility Phase; 6-month Pilot Phase. Phase 1: Feasibility Phase. Aim 1. This formative feasibility phase will include up to 20 participants who, in Phase II, will be randomized to different study arms. Our goal is to recruit 660 Black women over 2 years for Phase 1. The recruitment method will be informed by the results of the formative phase. Aim 1a. Identify the barriers and facilitators to detecting and treating binge eating in Black women with obesity and identify strategies for optimizing digital health tools. Participants will complete individual interviews in Phase I. Interviews will identify strategies for enrolling, retaining and motivating Black women over 6 months and to refine the digital tool. Participants who demonstrate a satisfactory retention rate for Phase 1 (> 90%) will be eligible to participate in Phase II. Aim 1b. Modify and adapt a validated program to be a culturally-relevant digital health tool for binge eating and weight management for Black women.

194.summary: Dietary nitrate supplementation, administered in the form of nitrate-rich beetroot juice, has been shown to improve exercise performance and may have more pronounced effects on exercise that requires high-power and high-velocity muscle contraction such as weightlifting and body-mass resisted exercise (i.e, resistance exercise). However, limited data are available that have examined the potential performance enhancing effect of beetroot juice in resistance exercise. Moreover, there is no information on the dose of nitrate required for performance enhancing effects during resistance exercise which limits its widespread use to enhance performance. Therefore, the investigators will assess if supplementing the diet with nitrate-rich beetroot juice impacts resistance exercise performance (e.g., power, velocity), when compared to supplementing the diet with nitrate-depleted beetroot juice (i.e. placebo). The investigators will also investigate the dose-response effect of beetroot juice on resistance exercise performance by providing a low, moderate, and high nitrate dose of concentrated beetroot juice. The results of this study will improve understanding of whether beetroot juice influences resistance exercise performance and will provide insight on whether different doses of beetroot juice influence the efficacy of nitrate supplementation on resistance exercise performance. Together, these data will guide supplementation strategies for enhancing resistance exercise performance.

The purpose of this study is to assess if dietary nitrate (NO3-) supplementation can enhance resistance exercise performance and muscle capacity to generate mechanical work. Specifically, we aim to investigate the effects of different levels of nitrate supplementation on the performance of a single set of heavy resistance exercise. We will explore two different modes of exercise: whole body (e.g., bench press, barbell back squat) and upper body (e.g., barbell bench press, preacher curls) resistance exercise. Investigators will collect data from 30 healthy, male recreational strength-trained individuals between the ages of 18 and 45. Participants will be invited into the study on four separate occasions (one per week), and will be provided (based on a computer-generated sequence) with four different beverages pre-exercise: 4 x 70 ml of nitrate-depleted beetroot juice shots for placebo (PL), 1 x 70 ml of nitrate-rich beetroot juice 3 x 70 ml nitrate-depleted beetroot juice shot for a low dose of nitrate-rich beetroot juice (BR-LOW; 6.5 mmol of nitrate total), 2 x 70 of nitrate-rich beetroot juice and 2 x 70ml of nitrate depleted beetroot juice shot for a moderate dose of nitrate-rich beetroot juice (BR-MOD; 13 mmol of nitrate total), and 4 x 70 ml of nitrate-rich beetroot juice for an elevated dose of nitrate-rich beetroot juice (BR-HIGH; 26 mmol of nitrate total). The 6 conditions will be presented in a fixed, counter-balanced order such that subjects will perform all 3 interventions in a crossover assignment in each muscle group.

195.summary:
In laparoscopic surgeries; a trocar is inserted through a small incision and an intervention is made into the peritoneal cavity. Approximately 3-4 liters of carbon dioxide (CO2) insufflation (inflating the abdominal cavity with carbon dioxide gas) is applied and the intra-abdominal pressure is adjusted to 10-20 mmHg. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy operation is routinely performed with 12 mmHg and 14 mmHg pressures in our operating room, and the preferred pressure value is; It is determined by the surgical team to be the most appropriate value for the patient and the operation. Both pressure values applied to the patients intraoperatively are within safe ranges.
The mechanical power of ventilation (MP) is the amount of energy transferred per unit time from the mechanical ventilator to the respiratory system. Although this energy is mainly used to overcome airway resistance, some of it directly affects the lung tissue, potentially causing ventilator induced lung injury (VILI). To prevent ventilator-associated lung injury, it requires the mechanical ventilator to be adjusted so that the least amount of energy is transferred to the respiratory system per unit time for each patient. In the results obtained in the published studies; increased mechanical strength has been associated with increased in-hospital mortality, higher hospital stay and higher ICU follow-up requirement.
The aim of this study is to investigate the effect of two different intra-operative intra-abdominal pressure levels applied to patients who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia on 'Mechanical Power (MP)'.
195.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Study Overview
=================
A total of 72 patients who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy will be included from December 2021 to April 2022. All patients recruited will be included in the study if they meet the inclusion criteria. Written and oral information will be obtained from the candidates to be included in the study. All candidates will be informed in writing again before the operation and the consent form will be signed by 2 people by the candidates.
Patients who are not volunteering will be excluded from the study before the operation. Patients who do not consent to the continuation of the study during the operation will be excluded. Patients with ASA 3-4 or patients who do not meet the other inclusion criteria will be excluded from the study. Patients with lung disease, other surgical procedures or anesthetic techniques, pregnant patients, and patients with morbid obesity who cannot tolerate surgery under general anesthesia or have contraindications to the study will be excluded from the study. Patients whose operation is determined to be converted from laparoscopic to laparotomy at any time for any reason after the incision is made will also be excluded. Data will be recorded from the electronic hospital record system. The records of all operations will be inspected and recorded in the study program. Anesthesia data in the operation chart of the patients will be used. If there are errors during data recording, these data will be re-evaluated by 2 experts in the surgical and anesthesia fields to correct the error again. Patients will be included in the groups after the insufflation pressure applied by the surgeon. The group where the insufflation pressure level is determined as 12 mmHg will be kept in group 12, and the group where the insufflation pressure level is determined by the surgeon as 14 mmHg will be kept in group 14. Mechanical power parameters of the patients will be measured using a pressure monitor (Puritan Bennett, Pennsylvania, USA) between December 2021-April 2022. Mechanical power values will be measured for 1 hour after the operation. Statistical power analysis has been performed to determine the number of patients to be included in the study. No statistically significant association was found between mean mechanical power and intraoperative complications in the study literature. In view of the results of the study, a sample size of 36 patients in each group was determined as appropriate to evaluate this relationship in cholecystectomy. The sample size in this study has been determined as sufficient to detect the difference in mechanical power between the 2 groups with at least 90% power at a significance level of 5%. The data recorded will be tabulated by SPSS 22.0. All data will be expressed in numbers, percentages, mean, median and standard deviation. Shapiro Wilk test will be used to evaluate data distribution in each section. Normally distributed data variables in the two groups will be compared using the independent or paired t-test (or Mann Whitney U test respectively). Non-normally distributed data variables; They will be evaluated with the chi-square test after testing the compliance of the data structure with the expected distribution with the Shapiro Wilk test. Correlation will be evaluated between variables in the normal distribution range. A p value below 0.05 will be considered statistically significant. The results obtained will be expressed in text, tables, and graphics in a clear and concise way. The results will be evaluated with statistical packages.

Official Title

Evaluation of the Effect of Two Different Intra-abdominal Pressure Applications on Mechanical Power in Cases Undergoing Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy

Conditions

Ventilator-induced Lung Injury

196.summary: Aim of this prospective study is to compare magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and cone beam computed tomography (CBCT) to diagnose furcation involvement (FI) in molars in patients with periodontitis. The focus is on the differentiation of grad II and III according to Hamp et al. 1975. 140 molars (70 upper and 70 lower) will be investigated with CBCT and MRI. Due to the absence of ionic radiation MRI might be a radiation free diagnostic tool to assess FI in the future without harmful radiation for the patient. Patients of the Dental Clinic, Medical University of Vienna, who need a CBCT and have a clinically diagnosed FI can be a participant of this clinical trial and do in addition to their CBCT a MRI. The accuracy of MRI will be compared to the diagnostic gold standard CBCT. If patients need additional periodontal treatment, e.g., periodontal surgery, a subgroup will also be analysed with intraoperative measurements.

Background: Furcation involvement of molars in deep class restorations is a common finding in patients with deep class restorations. Radiographic assessment is the most recommended technique for evaluation of furcation involvement when CBCT is not the method of choice. MRI might be an acceptable alternative to CBCT. Purpose: The main goal of this prospective study is to assess the extent of horizontal and vertical bone loss determined by MRI compared with CBCT in molars with deep class restorations and furcation involvement. We also aim to assess the correlation between MRI and CBCT in the measurement of furcation involvement. Methods: 60 subjects will be included sequentially by the clinical periodontal research group of the Department of Periodontology of the University of Graz. Patients included in the study must have full bone coverage as measured by CBCT (<1.5 mm) in at least one first molar with a deep class II or III restorations and furcation involvement in the apical third (grade II or III, according to Hamp 1975). MRI will be performed with the subject sitting in a fully loaded MRI scanner and with a 3.0 T MRI device (Siemens MAGNETOM Verio, Erlangen, Germany). Data on alveolar bone loss will be extracted for the mesial and distal roots of each molar in both CBCT and MRI examinations. Results and conclusion: If MRI is shown to be an acceptable alternative to CBCT, then further research will be needed for an alternative, non-invasive method. This will be of clinical importance for dentists, since it avoids intra-oral ionization radiation used in CBCT and is cost-effective, compared to regular CBCT assessment. It will also contribute to the development of a new method for evaluation of furcation involvement..

Study Title:
Pacing characteristics of a conventional bipolar, active fixation pacing lead for left bundle branch area pacing in patients with symptomatic bradycardia
Study Objectives:
To characterize an approach for left bundle branch area pacing (LBBAP) in patients with bradycardia indications for pacing and to assess implant success rate, safety, and long-term stability with a conventional bipolar, active fixation pacing lead.
Methodology: Open-label, prospective, multi-center, non-randomized, single-arm study
Study Endpoints:
Primary Endpoint:
• Implant success rate
Secondary Endpoints:
Intra-operative procedure time and fluoroscopic exposure time
Intra-operative intracardiac electrogram (EGM) changes: paced QRS duration, stimulus to left ventricular (LV) activation time, and LBB potential
Post-operative imaging data: posteroanterior, left anterior oblique 30O, right anterior oblique 30O, Left lateral views
Serial paced 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) and intracardiac EGM changes: QRS duration (QRSd), pacing-QRS interval, and new atrial ﬁbrillation (AF)
Serial echocardiography changes: left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), left atrial (LA) and LV chamber size, and global longitudinal strain (GLS) of tissue Doppler imaging
Serial changes of pacing parameters: capture threshold, impedance, and sensing amplitude for both atrial and ventricular Solia S leads
Safety:
Immediate (< 24 hours), in-hospital, and chronic (12 months) adverse events

199.summary:
Gingivitis in pregnant women is a common inflammatory periodontal disease that appears from the third month of pregnancy with an overall prevalence of 35 to 100%. This condition is induced by oral biofilm and exacerbated by increased levels of sex steroid hormones characteristic of pregnancy. Strict bacterial plaque control with both professional and home oral hygiene is essential. Manual toothbrushes require a more specific manual technique for women, while sonic electric toothbrushes, due to their ease of use, might be an excellent for oral individual prophylaxis. Therefore, the question of which type of manual or electric toothbrush might be more effective in reducing gingival inflammation in pregnant women is still unresolved. In literature there are a large number of in vitro clinical studies on this topic, there are currently no clinical studies investigating this long-term clinical comparison.
In this context, this study is a randomized clinical trial consisting of a comparative evaluation between two manual and two sonic electric toothbrushes in the efficacy of the control of plaque in order to reduce gingivitis in women during the period of pregnancy.
199.model_output:
<|assistant|>
Background: The objective of this clinical research is to evaluate the efficacy of two manual toothbrushes (CS 5460 and Oral-B 123) and two electric toothbrushes (DiamondClean 9000 Philips® and HydroSonic Easy Curaden®) when used daily by pregnant women over a 3-month period.
Objective: Assess the impact of the recommended brushing time (3 minutes minimum) of electric and manual toothbrushes on clinical parameters from baseline during pregnancy.
Methods: Randomized clinical comparative trial in parallel groups with controlled masking. Fifty-two women were recruited when they were in their first trimester of pregnancy and were randomly distributed into groups using sonic or manual toothbrushes or a combination of both. The initial evaluation is made at baseline (T1) and after 1 and 3 months (T2 and T3) by the principal investigator, independent of the randomization groups. The clinical parameters evaluated were: gingival bleeding (BI), number of sites with BI, gingival index (GI), plaque index (PI), clinical attachment (CAL), periodontal pocket (PTRPDEP), and Patient Satisfaction Score (PSS).
Intervention/Treatment: Participants at baseline were included in the trial in four experimental groups: Group 1 (n = 13), patients using a sonic toothbrush; Group 2 (n = 13), patients using manual with 5460 strands; Group 3 (n = 13), patients using manual toothbrush; Group 4 (n = 13), patients using two brushes during baseline.
Analysis: Qualitative and quantitative variables were presented by descriptive statistics: absolute and percentage frequency for qualitative variables; minimum, maximum, mean, median, and standard deviation for quantitative variables. An Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) was performed in the experimental groups, comparing changes from baseline in all parameters before and after treatment between the various groups.
Results: The mean plaque index before treatment (baseline) was similar between all experimental groups (PBS1 = 3.3±2.6; PBS2 = 3.3±2.6; PBS3 = 2.7±2.8; PBS4 = 3.4±2.7), except for the number of teeth (mean: PBS1 = 21.5±4.2; PBS2 = 21.4±4.7; PBS3 = 22.0±4.3; PBS4 = 21.4±4.6, p= 0.010). Over the evaluation period, there was a significant reduction in plaque (P < 0.0001) in all groups. However, no significant differences were observed between the groups using any toothbrush, the only difference being in the GI index with regard to the treatment performed (p= 0.000). The results of the study conclude that the two toothbrushes, sonic and hydrosonic, were as effective as the manual toothbrush to control gingival bleeding, gingival inflammation, and plaque control.
Ethical Considerations: This study is the direct result of the study of its investigators and a clear need to expand knowledge in this field, which was developed with the participation of the research group, taking into account the recommendations of the Declaration of Helsinki and the Research Ethics Board of Clínica São José of CIMO, Campinas, based on the National Law No. 7,194, of 17 December 1984 on the Registry of Clinical Trials, in force since August 18, 1986, in the state of São Paulo, Brazil.

Official Title
-----------------
Clinical Comparison of Two Sonic Electric Toothbrushes and Two Manual Toothbrushes, Used Under Normal Oral Hygiene Conditions, on the Reduction of Gingival Inflammation in Pregnant Women Aged 18 to 40: Randomized Clinical Trial

Conditions
-----------------
Pregnant Woman

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Device: Sonicare DiamondClean 9000 Philips®
* Device: HydroSonic Easy Curaden®
* Device: Manual toothbrush Oral-B 123
* Device: Manual toothbrush Curaprox CS 5460


Participation Criteria
=================
Eligibility Criteria
-----------------

200.summary:
The goal of this clinical trial is to learn if yoga-based breathing styles could improve memory performance in adult persons without relevant prior experience in yoga, meditation or similar disciplines and without existing health problems which could hinder the implementation of the breathing exercises.
The main questions it aims to answer are:
Can the memory performance get better ?
Can the subjective stress level be reduced ?
Participants will complete a memory test while doing a specific nasal and oral breathing.
They will complete a two-week training period after the test with daily nasal or mouth breathing training or no training at all, depending on the group, the are divided into.
Researchers will compare the effect of different breathing styles on memory ability among themselves.

The goal of this research is to learn about the effect of nasal and mouth breathing exercises on memory performance in people who have never practised yoga, meditation or other breathing methods before, without any prior health issues that could hamper their performance. After the initial memory test, the participants will complete a 14-day period of either nose or oral breathing training. After the follow-up test the researchers will compare nasal breathing group with oral breathing group and control group to gauge improvements in memory capacity.
